APPEALS:
Appellees' motion for reconsideration in USDC suspends
finality of judgment until USDC acts upon motion at
which time appellants may file timely notice of appeal.
See 414 U.S. 441. (72–1040) ---
Consideration of jurisdictional statement deferred to accord
counsel opportunity to secure a certificate from the
Supreme Court of Mississippi as to whether the judgment
herein was intended to rest on an adequate and inde-
pendent state ground or on federal grounds (73–628) ---
Dismissed, it appearing that appellant died (72–1681).
Dismissed for want of an appealable order (73–6459) –
Dismissed for want of jurisdiction, citing 28 U.S.C. 1257
(73–1139, 72–1173, 73–6272) ---

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1973
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1973 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
(The Attorney General thereupon presented Honorable Robert
Bork, Solicitor General of the United States.)
Mr. Elliot L. Richardson, Attorney General, said:
“Mr. Chief Justice :
"May it please the Court, I have the honor to present the new
Solicitor General, a distinguished scholar and practitioner of the law,
Robert Horn Bork, of Connecticut."
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Solicitor General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important office that you now assume, the duty of representing
the Government before this Court in all cases in which the Government
asserts an interest. Your commission will be duly recorded by the
Clerk."
ADMISSIONS OF ATTORNEYS DURING THE SUMMER RECESS
The following attorneys were admitted to the Bar of this Court by
action of single Justices during the summer recess, pursuant to the
Order of this Court entered on the twenty-fourth day of May, 1971:
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON WRITTEN MOTIONS.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
34
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1155. Francis J. Dixon, appellant, v. Carol J. Dixon. Ap-
peal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. Mo-
tion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 72-1448. Charles Ben Howell, appellant, v. Clarence Jones,
Sheriff, Dallas County, Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal
Appeals of Texas. Motion of Criminal Trial Lawyers Association of
Northern California for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1477. United States, appellant, v. Topco Associates, Inc.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 72–6995. Earl Jamerson et al., appellants, v. William M. Len-
nox, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argu-
ment.
No. 73–76. Lawrence Lung et al., appellants, v. Fred L. O'Cheskey
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
New Mexico. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73-118. Ammex Warehouse Company, Inc., et al., appellants,
2. Norman Gallman et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
540-278-73- -6



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
35
Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 72-1489. Texas, appellant, v. Johnnie Pruett. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of
appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set
case for oral argument.
No. 72-1535. Carmen C. Chimento, appellant, v. Robert L. Stark,
Secretary of State of New Hampshire. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of New Hampshire. Motion to dispense
with printing jurisdictional statement granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72-1571. Marlene M. Schwartz, etc., appellant, v. Warren
Talmo, dba Warren's Masonry, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 72-1586. Ronald K. Campbell et al., appellants, v. Oregon.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1626. S. Parkman Shaw et al., Trustees, appellants, v.
Commissioner of Corporations & Taxation of the Commonwealth of
Massachusetts; and
No. 72-1627. Thomas Bell Frost, Executor, etc., appellant, v.
Commissioner of Corporations & Taxation of the Commonwealth of
Massachusetts. Appeals from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. The appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 72-1670. Texad, Inc. (Texad Specialty Company), appellant,
v. Parish of St. Mary Sales and Use Tax Department. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1735. Insurance Company of North America, appellant, v.
C. Austin Montgomery, Director of Financial Institutions of Illi-
nois. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-6984. Ronald J. Gerard, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-5. Simanco, Inc., appellant, v. Wisconsin Department of
Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–123. California, appellant, v. Mary Louise Jones et al. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dis-



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
36
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73–148. Meyer Shapiro, etc., appellant, v. City of New York
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-1675. National Motor Freight Traffic Association, Inc., et
al., appellants, v. United States et al.; and
No. 72-1676. Bray Lines, Inc., et al., appellants, v. United States
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed.
No. 72–1682. Joseph Shelofsky et al., appellants, v. Robert D.
Helsby et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 72-6413. Marjorie Nuttall, appellant, v. Department of Social
Welfare of California et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. Motion to defer consideration
denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6628. Javier Harvey Viramontes, appellant, v. California.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6757. Charles A. DunLeavay, appellant, v. Christabel Hal-
lahan et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6832. Russell F. Long, appellant, v. A. W. Gammill, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division One.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6932. James E. Diggs, Jr., appellant, v. George P. Hall et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–138. Bunge Corporation, appellant, v. Federal Barge
Lines, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
37
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 73-5019. Miguel A. Gargallo, appellant, v. Tecla Gargallo.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72–6900. Jane Doe, etc., appellant, v. Planned Parenthood As-
sociation of Utah. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–213. Rhilda Jean Fortier, aka Rhilda Jean Fontaine, ap-
pellant, v. Project Hope, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note prob-
able jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–215. Arthur Falkner et ux., appellants, v. Ralph B. Fer-
guson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge, etc., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Motion
to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal
is dismissed. Mengelkoch v. Industrial Welfare Commission, 393 U.S.
83 (1968) and Wilson v. City of Port Lavaca, 391 U.S. 352 (1968).
No. 73–216. Arthur Falkner et ux., appellants, v. Ralph B. Fer-
guson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge, etc., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Motion to
dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mengelkoch v. Industrial Wel-
fare Commission, 393 U.S. 83 (1968).
No. 73–249. Union Pacific Railroad Company, appellant, v. John
H. Heckers, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas concurs, being of the view that a corporation is not a
"person" within the meaning of the Equal Protection Clause of the
Fourteenth Amendment. Wheeling Steel Corporation v. Glander, 337
U.S. 562, 576-581 (Douglas, J., dissenting).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–1210. International Association of Machinists and Aero-
space Workers, AFL-CIO, Local Lodge No. 504, et al., petitioners,
v. David O'Reilly et al.; and



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
38
No. 72-1502. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Mor-
ton Salt Company et al. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petitions for
writs of certiorari granted, judgments vacated and cases remanded.
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of National
Labor Relations Board v. The Boeing Company, 412 U.S. 67 (1973).
No. 72-1485. Board of Regents of the University of Texas Sys-
tem, petitioner, v. New Left Education Project et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of Texas with directions to dismiss the case as moot. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas dissents from vacating the judgment below.
No. 72-1678. William Carey, Warden, et al., petitioners v. Wayne
E. Gammons. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Cady v. Dombrowski, 413 U.S.
-(1973). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the vacation and remand.
No. 72-6454. Robert M. Hanahan, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois for reconsideration in light of the suggestion con-
tained in the Solicitor General's memorandum filed July 3, 1973.
No. 72–6690. Joel Nat Lee, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Florida with directions to dismiss the indictment. The
Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun dissent for the reasons
stated in the dissenting opinion of Mr. Justice Blackmun in Durham
v. United States, 401 U.S. 481, 483–485 (1971). See Bradley v. United
States, 404 U.S. 567 (1972).
No. 72-6812. Patrick D. Chenoweth, petitioner, v. John W. War-
ner, Secretary of the Navy, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California with
directions to dismiss the case as moot.



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
39
No. 72-6836. James Russell, petitioner, v. Glenn Douthitt. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Indiana for further consideration in light of
Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778 (1973).
No. 73-6. The Building and Construction Trades Council of Phil-
adelphia and Vicinity, petitioner, v. Bernard L. Samoff, Regional
Director, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania
with directions to dismiss the case as moot.
No. 73–217. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Peter Campana et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgments
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District, to consider whether its judgments are based on
federal or state constitutional grounds, or both. See California v.
Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972). Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the
vacation and remand.
No. 73-5053. Robert J. Scarpa, petitioner, v. U.S. Board of Pa-
role et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for considera-
tion of the question of mootness. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Telephone Users Association, Inc., petitioner, v. Pub-
lic Service Commission of District of Columbia et al. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. A-106. Willis Howard Raymond, applicant, v. J. B. Gunn,
Warden. The application for a writ of habeas corpus presented to
Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-230. James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing & Urban Devel-
opment, applicant, v. Pennsylvania et al. The motion to vacate the
stay entered by the Chief Justice on August 29, 1973, or in the alter-
native for an order for applicant to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari before judgment, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
vacate the stay.



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
40
No. A-288. Kevin J. Burns, Acting Commissioner of Iowa De-
partment of Social Services, et al., applicants, v. Linda Alcala et al.
The application for stay of judgment of the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Iowa presented to Mr. Justice
Blackmun, and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending
final disposition on appeal in the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit in case No. 73–1595. Mr. Justice Douglas
would deny the application.
No. D-10. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank G. Kirtz. It hav-
ing been reported to this Court that Frank G. Kirtz, of St. Louis, Mis-
souri, has been disbarred from the practice of law in all of the courts
of the State of Missouri, and this Court by order of June 11, 1973,
having suspended the said Frank G. Kirtz from the practice of law
in this Court and directed that a rule issue requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and the United
States Marshal attempted to serve respondent and said respondent re-
fused to accept service and that the time within which to file a return
has expired;
It is ordered that the said Frank G. Kirtz be, and he is hereby, dis-
barred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys to practice before the Bar of this
Court.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of Ar-
kansas. The exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are set
for oral argument in due course.
No. 62, Original. State of Nevada, plaintiff, v. State of Califor-
nia; and
No. 63, Original. State of Georgia, plaintiff, v. Richard M. Nixon,
President of the United States, et al. The motions for leave to file bills
of complaint are denied.
No. 64, Original. State of New Hampshire, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine. The motion for leave to file bill of complaint is granted and the
State of Maine is allowed thirty days in which to answer or otherwise
respond.
No. 71-1545. Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Glover Livestock Commission Company, Inc. The motion
to waive costs is denied.
No. 72-397. Bonelli Cattle Company et al., petitioners, v. Arizona
et al. The motion of the State of California for leave to participate in
oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied. The motion of County of
Mohave for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 72-481. Department of Game of the State of Washington, pe-
titioner, v. The Puyallup Tribe et al.; and



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1973
41
No. 72–746. Puyallup Tribe, petitioner, v. Department of Game of
the State of Washington. The motion of Ramona C. Bennett et al. for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of the Na-
tional Congress of American Indians, Inc., et al., for leave to file a
brief, as amici curiae, in No. 72-746, is granted.
No. 72–490. McDonnell Douglas Corporation, petitioner, v. Percy
Green. The motion of respondent to retax costs is denied.
No. 72-671. Cecilia Espinoza and Rudolfo Espinoza, petitioners,
v. Farah Manufacturing Company, Inc. The motion of Facilities Man-
agement Corporation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
denied.

Carol LaFleur et al.; and

the National Education Association et al., for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae, is granted. The motion of International Union of Elec-
trical Radio and Machine Workers, AFL-CIO for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of Margaret M. Broussard for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, and to dispense with printing is
granted. The motion of the International Association of Official Hu-
man Rights Agencies for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in
No. 72–777, is granted. The motion of State of Maryland Commission
on Human Relations et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in
No. 72–1129, is granted. The motion of the Delta Air Lines, Inc., for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, in No. 72-1129, is granted.
No. 72-847. Memorial Hospital et al., appellants v. Maricopa
County et al. The motion of the Legal Aid Society of Maricopa County
for leave to dispense with printing the amicus curiae brief is denied.
No. 72-888. H. Keith Zahn et al., petitioners, v. International
Paper Company. The motion of Lloyd E. Canfield et al. for leave to file
a brief, as amici curiae, is denied. The motion of Consumers Union of
United States, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.

James Rhodes et al.; and

72-914, is denied. The motion of the National Bar Association for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, iin No. 72-1318, is granted.

et al. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.

or prohibition denied.

ORAL ARGUMENT
Parsons.
No. 71-1669. James E. Gustafson, petitioner, v. Florida, Argued
by Mr. James M. Russ for the petitioner and by Mr. Barry Scott Rich-
ard for the respondent.
No. 72–936. United States, petitioner, v. Willie Robinson, Jr. Ar-
gued by Mr. Allan A. Tuttle for the petitioner and by Mr. Joseph V.
Gartlan, Jr., for the respondent.

540-278-73-18



(Journal)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1973
113
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marsh-
all, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rhen-
quist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with
the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72-552. Robert Satiacum, petitioner, v. Washington. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Washington for resolution by the
state courts of the factual issue whether the alleged offenses took place
outside the boundaries of what is, or was, the Reservation. Opinion per
curiam.
No. 72-6897. Harold R. Plummer, appellant, v. City of Columbus,
Ohio. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin
County, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Blackmun dissent for the reasons expressed in Mr. Justice Blackmun's
dissenting opinion in Gooding v. Wilson, 405 U.S. 518, 534 (1972),
and in the dissenting opinion in Cason v. City of Columbus, 409
U.S. 1053 (1972). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurs.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1519. Emmett Dunlavey et al., appellants, v. John
Berenguer et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Delaware. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the District Court with directions to dismiss case as moot.
No. 72-1681. Larry Hampton, appellant, v. Stanley Ditty. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. It appearing that the appel-
lant, who sought to enjoin a state criminal proceeding against him,
died on January 20, 1973, appeal dismissed. Gersewitz v. New York,
326 U.S. 687 (1945); Pennsylvania v. Linde, 409 U.S. 1031 (1972).
540-278-73--19



MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1973
114
See Durham v. United States, 401 U.S. 481, 482 (1971). Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-1718. Stephen Gaskin et al., appellants, . Tennessee.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division. The
appeal is dimissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-69. Ronald Stephen Haulcomb and Kenneth Pinneau,
appellants, c. South Carolina. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
South Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 72–1736. Harry White, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
No. 72-6629. A. B. Thompson, Jr., et al., appellants, c. Missis-
sippi. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72–6634. Tyler Henry Smith, II, appellant. v. Superior Court
of California, Alameda County. Appeal from the Court of Appeal
of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 72-6659. Tyler Henry Smith, II, appellant, v. Superior Court
of California, County of Alameda, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 72-6822. Francisco Cepero Alers, appellant, v. Ramon Negron
Soto, Judge, Superior Court of Puerto Rico. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Puerto Rico. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–79. Royal Jennings, appellant, v. Sam G. Canott. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Iowa. Motion to dispense with printing
jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-94. United States Steel Corporation, appellant, v. Trustees
of Penn Central Transportation Company. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.



MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1973
115
No. 73–5046. Robert Lee Stokes, appellant, v. Edward Bruce et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom the Chief Justice concurs.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1721. Louie L. Wainwright, Director, Florida Division of
Corrections, petitioner, v. Ernest Jackson Cottle. On petition for writ

cuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs.

petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Almeida-Sanchez v. United States, U.S. (1973).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-335. Margaret Anne Heutsche, applicant, v. United States.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. A-344. Sigurd Hansen, applicant, v. Carolyn Aiello et al. The
application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun, and by him
referred to the Court, is granted pending further order of the Court.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The application for temporary restraining order, preliminary injunc-
tion, and other relief is referred to the Special Master. The Report of
the Special Master on Louisiana's motion to enlarge the reference to
the Special Master to include the establishment of Louisiana's lateral
boundary with Texas in the Gulf of Mexico, including the briefing
schedule contained therein, is received, ordered filed and adopted.
No. 72-397. Bonelli Cattle Company et al., petitioners, v. Arizona
et al. The motion of the Cocopak Tribe of Indians for leave to file an
untimely brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-403. Arthur F. Sampson, Administrator, General Services
Administration, et al., petitioners, v. Jeanne M. Murray. The motion
of the respondent to permit Thomas J. McGrew to argue pro hac vice
is granted.
No. 72-777. Cleveland Board of Education et al., petitioners, v.
Jo Carol LaFleur et al.; and
No. 72-1129. Susan Cohen, petitioner, v. Chesterfield County
School Board et al. The motion of the Chamber of Commerce of the
United States for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 72-782. Gateway Coal Company, petitioner, v. United Mine
Workers of America et al. The motion of Frederick McAllister et al.
for leave to file an untimely brief, as amici curiae, is denied.
No. 72-822. The Renegotiation Board, petitioner, v. Bannercraft
Clothing Company, Inc., et al. The motion of Sears, Roebuck & Co.,
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 72-851. The Oneida Indian Nation of New York State et al.,
petitioners, v. The County of Oneida, New York, et al. The motion of



MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1973
117
the State of New York for leave to participate in oral argument, as
amicus curiae, in support of the respondents is granted and the State
of New York is to confine oral argument to the questions presented.
The motion for additional time to present oral argument is denied.
No. 72-1162. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. New
England Power Company et al. The motion of the respondents for
additional time for oral argument is granted and fifteen minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The petitioner is allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 72-1180. Old Dominion Branch No. 496, National Association
of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO, et al., appellants, v Henry M. Austin
et al. The motion of the appellants for additional time for oral argu-
ment is denied. The motion of the appellees for divided argument is
granted.
No. 72-1188. James R. Schlesinger, Secretary of Defense, et al.,
petitioners, v. Reservists Committee to Stop the War et al. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General for additional time for oral argument is
granted and 15 additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. The
respondents are allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 72-1318. Arthur Krause, Administrator of the Estate of
Allison Krause, et al., petitioners, v. James Rhodes et al. The motion
of the petitioners for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 72-5847. Harrell Alexander, Sr., petitioner, v. Gardner-
Denver Company. The motion of the Chamber of Commerce of the
United States for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, is denied.
No. 72-6580. Operative Plasterers and Cement Masons Inter-
national Union Local 685, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Texaco, Inc. The
motion of the petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied without prejudice to file printed petition in conformity with
Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court and to pay the Clerk's cost on or
before November 14, 1973.
No. 73-40. William O. Wallace, Acting Warden, petitioner, v.
Edward Lee Smith. The motion to dispense with printing the petition
is denied with leave to file a printed petition in conformity with Rule
39 of the Rules of this Court on or before November 14, 1973.
No. 73-392. Jerome Daly, petitioner, v. United States. The appli-
cation for bail presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. 73–5213. Harry R. Fawcett and George Manuel, petitioners,
v. United States. The application by Manuel for stay presented to Mr.
Justice Marshall, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

order heretofore entered by this Court on June 18, 1973, is hereby

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit beginning in November 1973
and for such further time as may be required to complete unfinished
business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a), is ordered entered on the
minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, October 23, 1973, until
Monday, November 5, 1973.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973
134
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72-1652. United States Immigration and Naturalization Serv-
ice, petitioner, v. Marciano Haw Hibi. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
No. 72-6449. John Elwood Dennett, petitioner, v. Marvin R. Ho-
gan, Warden. On motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas
corpus. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Upon
the suggestion of the Solicitor General to treat the papers submitted as
a petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit, petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1510. Cinema Classics, Ltd., Inc., et al.. appellants, v. Jo-
seph P. Busch, Jr., District Attorney, Los Angeles County, California,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central
District of California. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-1558. Betty M. Stein et al., appellants, v. Lewisville Inde-
pendent School District et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals
of Texas, Second Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
540-278-73--24



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973
135
No. 72-6917. Philip Charlton Zweig and Morton Alexander Zus-
serman, appellants, v. California. Appeal from the Appellate Depart-
ment of the Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 73-5202. Julian Felder, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note
probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–104. Charles Kirkpatrick and Peter Dargis, appellants, v.
New York. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Marshall concur. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 73–128. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, appellant,
v. Vern Miller, Attorney General of the State of Kansas, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Kansas.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–212. Judy Procaccini et al., appellants, v. Clarence Jones
et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Eleventh
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-5237. Carroll M. House, appellant, v. St. Agnes Hospital,
Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–1296. Robert O. Carlson et al., petitioners, v. Minnesota.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Minnesota for further consideration
in light of Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris Adult Thea-
tre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49 (1973); Kaplan v. California, 413 U.S. 115
(1973); United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Super 8mm. Film, 413 U.S.
123 (1973); United States v. Orito, 413 U.S. 139 (1973); Heller v.
New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413 U.S. 496
(1973); and Alexander v. Virginia, 413 U.S. — (1973). Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
•



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973
136
Brennan, with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
No. 72–1487. James M. Trinkler, petitioner, v. Alabama. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Ala-
bama. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgments vacated, and
case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for
further consideration in light of Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15
(1973); Paris Adult Theater I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49 (1973); Kaplan
v. California. 413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of
Super 8mm. Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973); United States v. Orito, 413
U.S. 139 (1973); Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden v.
Kentucky. 413 U.S. 496 (1973): and Alexander v. Virginia, 413 U.S.
- (1973). Dissenting opinion by Mr Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Marshall con-
cur. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.

Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petitions for writs of cer-

tive courts for further consideration in light of Miller v. California,
413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49
(1973) ; Kaplan v. California, 413 U.S. 115 (1973) ; United States v. 12
200-ft Reels of Super 8mm. Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973); United States
v. Orito. 413 U.S. 139 (1973); Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483
(1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413 U.S. 496 (1973); and Alexander v.
Virginia, 413 U.S836 (1973). Dissenting opinion in each case by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.

writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973
137
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District, for further considera-
tion in light of Wardius v. Oregon, 412 U.S. 470 (1973). Mr. Justice
Douglas would grant certiorari and set case for oral argument.
No. 73–259. Edwin L. Wiegand Company, petitioner, v. Josephine
Jurinko and Ida M. Seibert. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of McDonnell
Douglas Corp. v. Green, 411 U.S. 792 (1973).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-11. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Benjamin Gerard
Hartzog. It is ordered that Benjamin Gerard Hartzog, of Washing-
ton, D.C., be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. D-12. In the Matter of the Disbarment of John T. Isaacson. It
is ordered that John T. Isaacson, of St. Louis, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, return-
able within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-13. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Isadore Albert
Lehrer. It is ordered that Isadore Albert Lehrer, of Washington, D.C.,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-14. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Douglas C. Mac-
Leod. It is ordered that Douglas C. MacLeod, of St. Louis, Missouri,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-15. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Marshall Howard
Sevin. It is ordered that Marshall Howard Sevin, of Century City,
California, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. 72-887. American Party of Texas et al., appellants, v. Mark
White, Jr., Secretary of State of Texas; and



TUESDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1973
138
No. 72-942. Robert Hainsworth, appellant, v. Mark White, Jr.,
Secretary of State of Texas. The motion for additional time for oral
argument on behalf of the appellants is granted and ten additional
minutes are allotted for that purpose. The appellants in No. 72-887
shall have a total of twenty minutes for oral argument and the ap-
pellant in No. 72-942 shall have a total of twenty minutes for oral
argument. The appellee in these cases is allotted ten additional min-
utes for oral argument for a total of forty minutes. The motions of
appellants for divided argument are granted and it is ordered that
Gloria Tanner Svanas be permitted to present oral argument on be-
half of appellants in No. 72-887, and Robert W. Hainsworth, Esquire,
be permitted to present oral argument pro se in No. 72–942.
No. 72-888. H. Keith Zahn et al., petitioners, v. International Pa-
per Company. The motion of Consumers Union of United States, Inc.
for reconsideration of the order denying leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 72-1371. Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal
Revenue, petitioner, v. "Americans United" Inc. et al. The motion of
the respondents to permit two counsel to argue orally is granted.
No. 72-1465. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California De-
partment of Corrections, et al., appellants, v. Robert Martinez et al.
The motion of the Boston University Center for Criminal Justice for
leave to file its brief amicus curiae in unprinted form is denied.
No. 72-5847. Harrell Alexander, Sr., petitioner, v. Gardner-
Denver Company. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and a total
of fifteen minutes is allotted for that purpose. The respondent is
allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 73-187. Kewanee Oil Company, petitioner, v. Bicron Corpora-
tion et al. The motion of the Bar Association of the District of Colum-
bia for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae. is denied. The motion of
the Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–578. Stanley Yassen, petitioner, v. United States. The ap-
plication for stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.

(Journal)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1973
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
152
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally".
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 72–1366. Edward Norwell, petitioner, v. City of Cincinnati,
Ohio. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Ohio. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
No. 72-6915. Richard J. Taylor, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion per curiam.
No. 73-122. Louie L. Wainwright, Director, Division of Correc-
tions, et al., appellants, v. Raymond R. Stone & Eugene F. Huffman.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.
No. 73-5002. Rockey Moore, petitioner, v. Arizona. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Arizona to reassess petitioner's case under the standards mandated
by Smith v. Hooey, 393 U.S. 374 (1969); Barker v. Wingo, 407 U.S.
514 (1972); and Dickey v. Florida, 398 U.S. 30 (1970). Opinion per
curiam.
No. 73-5245. Richard Berry, petitioner, v. City of Cincinnati,
Ohio. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio.
Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
540-278-73- -27



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1973
153
of certiorari granted. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–1582. Carl A. Johnson, appellant, v. City of Cheyenne,
Wyoming, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. Mo-
tion to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 73-10. Carl A. Johnson, appellant, v. Laramie County School
District No. 1. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. Motion
to dispense with printing jurisdictional statement granted. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 72-1612. John Martin Connor, appellant, v. Arkansas. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-6799. Kenneth Dale Canfield, appellant, v. Oklahoma.
Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 72-6880. Bailey M. Smith et ux., appellants, v. Harry G.
Reeder et ux. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Divi-
sion 2. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-273. Louis Montenegro et al., appellants, v. New Jersey
et al.; and
No. 73-274. Meadowlands Regional Development Agency et al.,
appellants, v. New Jersey et al. Appeals from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. The appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 73–275. The Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company
et al., appellants, v. Louisiana;
No. 73-335. Illinois Central Railroad Company, etc., appellant,
v. Louisiana;
No. 73-340. Southern Pacific Transportation Company, appellant,
v. Louisiana;
No. 73-341. The Texas Pacific-Missouri Pacific Terminal Rail-
road of New Orleans, appellant, v. Louisiana; and
No. 73-342. Louisiana & Arkansas Railway Company, appellant,
v. Louisiana. Appeals from the Twenty-fourth Judicial District Court
of Louisiana, Parish of Jefferson. The appeals are dismissed for want



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1973
154
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of No. 73–275.
No. 72–1630. Board of Education of Tri-Valley Central School
District No. 1 of the Towns of Neversink, Fallsburg, Liberty, et al.,
appellants, v. Board of Cooperative Educational Services of the Sole
Supervisory District of Sullivan County. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 73-5303. Charles A. DunLeavay, appellant, v. Lutz Appel-
late Printers, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 72-6749. Donald Owens, appellant, v. Eugene Gold, District
Attorney, Kings County, New York. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-320. Joseph Pirincin et al., appellants, v. Board of Elec-
tions of Cuyahoga County et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Ohio. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-336. Catherine Catoor, etc., et al., appellants, v. Allan L.
Blair, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1576. Little Art Corporation, petitioner, v. Nebraska. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska; and
No. 73-4. Gay Times, Inc., petitioner, v. Louisiana. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Petitions for
writs of certiorari granted, judgments vacated, and cases remanded to
the respective courts for further consideration in light of Miller v. Cali-
fornia, 413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S.
49 (1973); Kaplan v. California, 413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States
v. 12 200-ft Reels of Super 8mm. Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973); United
States v. Orito, 413 U.S. 139 (1973); Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483
(1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413 U.S. 496 (1973); and Alexander v.
Virginia, 413 U.S. 836 (1973). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
concur. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-6914. Lamar Robbins, petitioner, v. Tennessee. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Ten-
nessee, Eastern Division. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Tennessee, East-



1
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1973
155
ern Division, for further consideration in light of the decision of
the Supreme Court of Tennessee in Lee Franklin v. State of Tennes-
see, dated June 18, 1973. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari
and set case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-335. Margaret Anne Heutsche, applicant, v. United States.
The reapplication for bail presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and
by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant the application.
No. A-420. Warden, Lewisburg Penitentiary, petitioner, v. Be-
nigno Marrero. The motion of the respondent to vacate the stay en-
tered by Mr. Justice Brennan on October 25, 1973, is denied.
No. A-421. Allan G. Kaplan, applicant, v. Amalgamated Lithog-
raphers of America, Local One, et al. The application for stay pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. 64, Original. State of New Hampshire, plaintiff, v. State of
Maine. The Honorable Tom C. Clark, Associate Justice of the Su-
preme Court (Retired) is appointed Special Master.
No. 72-914. Sarah Scheuer, Administratix, etc., petitioner, v.
James Rhodes et al.; and
No. 72-1318. Arthur Krause, Administrator of the Estate of
Allison Krause, et al., petitioners, v. James Rhodes et al. The motion
of Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-1154. John P. Foley, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Blair & Co.,
Inc., et al. Consideration of respondents' suggestion of mootness is de-
ferred to the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 72-1168. United States, petitioner, v. Thomas E. Maze. The
motion of respondent for the appointment of counsel is granted, and
it is ordered that William T. Warner, Esquire, of Louisville, Ken-
tucky, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 72-1410. Joel Edelman, Director of Illinois Department of
Public Aid, etc., petitioner, v. John Jordan et al. The motion of
NLSP Center on Social Welfare Policy and Law, Inc., for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-6520. Kinney Kinmon Lau, a minor by and through Mrs.
Kam Wai Lau, his guardian ad litem, et al, Petitioners, v. Alan H.
Nichols, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of peti-



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1973
156
tioners is granted and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that
purpose. The respondents are allotted fifteen additional minutes for
oral argument.
No. 72–6902. Lonnie Gooding, petitioner, v. United States. The
motion of the petitioner for the appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Herbert A. Rosenthal, of Washington, D. C., a
member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 73–187. Kewanee Oil Company, petitioner, v. Bicron Corpo-
ration et al. The motion of the petitioner with respect to limited
printing of the record is granted.
No. 73–298. Ramon G. Vela et al., appellants, v. Raymond W.
Vowell et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing
the views of the United States.
No. 73-5426. Robert O. O'Reilly, petitioner, v. United States.
The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 72–1454. Joseph Anthony Davis, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 73–263. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v.
Idaho Power Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 72-1513. Con F. Shea, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Ascension
Vialpando. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED

The Chief Justice said:
Laytonsville, Md. Joseph Andrew
"Before we hear the first argument this morning, we would like to
take note for the permanent journal and records of the Court of an
important event in the history of the Court.
"One week ago today, on October 29th, Mr. Justice Douglas estab-
lished a new longevity record for service on The Supreme Court of the
United States: thirty-four years, one hundred and ninety-six days, as
of that day.
"His tenure as a Justice of this Court now exceeds that of Mr. Jus-
tice Stephen Field, who was appointed by President Lincoln, took his
oath of office in 1863, on May 20th, and remained on the Court until
December 1, 1897.
"I know I speak for all the members of the Court, and for the re-
tired and former members of the Court, when we take this occasion to
wish our Brother Douglas continued good health and long life and
to record our congratulations on the new record which he has estab-
lished and will proceed to break every day when he arrives at the
Court in the morning."

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1973
178
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with
the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 72-1733. Christopher Joseph Musser, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; and
No. 72–6748. Robert Haines Waldron, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner Waldron in
No. 72–6748 for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions
for writs of certiorari granted and judgments affirmed. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari and set cases for
oral argument.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–359. Pennsylvania et al., appellants, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle District
of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–378. Norman L. Fuld et al., appellants, v. Donald H.
Elliott, Chairman of the City Planning Commission and Director of
City Planning et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–270. Norman Eakes, petitioner, v. South Dakota. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of South Dakota for further consid-
eration in light of Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris
Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49 (1973); Kaplan v. California,
413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Super 8mm.
540-278-73-32



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1973
179
Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973) ; United States v. Orito, 413 U.S. 139 (1973);
Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413
| U.S. 496 (1973); and Alexander v. Virginia, 413 U.S. 836 (1973).
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall concur. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-5054. Donald Alan Bush, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. On the representation of
the Solicitor General set forth in his memorandum for the United
States filed October 17, 1973, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of the position pres-
ently asserted by the Government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-472. Arhur Burghardt Banks, applicant, v. Cale J. Holder,
United States District Judge. The application for acceleration of
the filing of the petitions for writs of certiorari presented to Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-16. In the Matter of Disbarment of Herbert S. Mades. It is
ordered that Herbert S. Mades of Winthrop, Mass., be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue returnable
within forty days requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-17. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles E. Englert.
It is ordered that Charles E. Englert of Boston, Mass., be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue returnable
within forty days requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-18. In the Matter of Disbarment of John J. Stanton. It is
ordered that John J. Stanton, of Boston, Mass., be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue returnable within
forty days requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this court.
No. 72-1125. A. Y. Allee et al., appellants, v. Francisco Medrano
et al. The motion of Mexican American Legal Defense and Educa-
tional Fund for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 72–1660. Stanley Blackledge, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Jimmy Seth Perry. The motion of the respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The motion for the appointment of coun-



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1973
180
sel is granted, and it is ordered that James E. Keenan, Esquire, of
Durham, N.C., a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby,
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 73-297. Alliance for Consumer Protection-Hill District
Branch et al., petitioners, v. Milk Marketing Board of the Common-
wealth of Pennsylvania et al. The motion to dispense with printing the
petition is denied with leave to file a printed petition in conformity
with Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court on or before December 12,
1973.

ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the week of November 26,
1973, and for such additional time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of New York during the month of
December 1973, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a). is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1973
189
of Appeals for the Second Circuit during the period April 15, 1974,
to April 19, 1974, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, November 19, 1973, to
Monday, December 3, 1973.

540-278-73--35



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1973
196
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73-5290. Gregory Hess, appellant, v. Indiana. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Indiana. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Indiana for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 73–382. Portland Pipe Line Corporation, appellant, v. En-
vironmental Improvement Commission et al.; and
No. 73–383. American Oil Company et al., appellants, v. Environ-
mental Improvement Commission et al. Appeals from the Supreme
Judicial Court of Maine. The appeals are dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stewart would dismiss the ap-
peals for want of a properly presented federal question. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these appeals.
No. 73–399. Aberdeen and Rockfish Railroad Company et al.,
appellants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(S.C.R.A.P) et al.; and
No. 73–420. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures
(S.C.R.A.P) et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for
the District of Columbia. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for
further consideration in light of Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Rail-
way Co. v. Wichita Board of Trade, 412 U.S. 800 (1973). Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these appeals.
540-278-73--36



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1973
197
No. 73-404. Dependent School District No. D-20 of Caddo
County, Oklahoma, et al., appellants, v. B. E. Parker, County Super-
intendent of Schools of Caddo County, Oklahoma. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 73-5391. Larry Wayne Wood, appellant, v. Virginia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-415. Roger W. Titus, appellant, v. Supreme Court of
Virginia et al.; and
No. 73–416. Allison W. Brown, Jr., appellant, v. Supreme Court
of Virginia et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice White
would note probable jurisdiction and set cases for oral argument.
No. 73–426. John C. Danforth, Attorney General of Missouri,
appellant, v. Samuel U. Rodgers, M.D., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Missouri. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 73-5314. Charles B. Mitchell, appellant, v. Workmen's Com-
pensation Appeals Board of California et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. Motion of California
Applicant's Attorneys Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly pre-
sented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-6681. Leslie Elder, Jr., petitioner, v. Major Joe Casey et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Tennessee for reconsideration in light of the suggestion
contained in the Solicitor General's memorandum filed Ocober 26,
1973. Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari and set case for
oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-486. Environmental Defense Fund et al., applicants, v.
Tennessee Valley Authority et al. The application for stay presented
to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
No. D–19. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Robert R. Mc-
Whinney. It is ordered that Robert R. McWhinney, of Greensburg,



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1973
198
Pennsylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him
to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of
law in this Court.
No. D-20. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Robert Bernard
Levin. It is ordered that Robert Bernard Levin, of New York City,
New York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D-21. In the Matter of the Disbarment of George Gordon
Liddy. It is ordered that George Gordon Liddy, of Oxon Hill, Mary-
land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 73-187. Kewanee Oil Company, petitioner, v. Bicron Corpo-
ration et al. The motion of SCM Corporation for access to the totality
of the appendix is denied.
No. 73-275. The Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company
et al., appellants, v. Louisiana;
No. 73-335. Illinois Central Railroad Company, etc., appellant,
v. Louisiana;
No. 73-340. Southern Pacific Transportation Company, appellant,
v. Louisiana;
No. 73-341. The Texas Pacific-Missouri Pacific Terminal Rail-
road of New Orleans, appellant, v. Louisiana; and
No. 73–342. Louisiana & Arkansas Railway Company, appellant,
v Louisiana, The order of the Court entered on November 5, 1973, dis-
missing the appeals for want of a substantial federal question is
amended by deleting the sentence which reads "Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of No. 73–275" and substitut-
ing in lieu thereof "Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these appeals."
No. 73-431. Joseph L. Broccolino, Jr., petitioner, v. Maryland
Commission on Judicial Disabilities et al. The motion to dispense with
printing the petition is denied with leave to file a printed petition in
conformity with Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court on or before
December 19, 1973.
No. 73-5481. Geneva H. Sayles, appellant, v. Matthew F. Mc-
Guire, Judge, U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The
application for injunction presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.

a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted.

Prince Frederick,
Francis B. Burch.
Md.
OPINIONS
No. 72-671. Cecilia Espinoza and Rudolfo Espinoza, petitioners,
v. Farah Manufacturing Company, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas.



MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1973
210
No. 72-331. Louis J. Lefkowitz et al., appellants, v. M. Russell
Turley et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Separate statement by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71-1631. Stanley T. Kusper, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Harriet
G. Pontikes et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in the result. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 72-481. Department of Game of the State of Washington,
petitioner, v. The Puyallup Tribe et al.; and
No. 72–746. Puyallup Tribe, petitioner, v. Department of Game
of the State of Washington. On writs of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Washington. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
Supreme Court of Washington for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Stewart join.
No. 72-922. Mary Louise Green Paschall et al., appellants, v.
Christie-Stewart, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Oklahoma. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Oklahoma for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart concurs.
Adjourned until Monday, December 3, 1973, at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1973

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
A-435. Life of the Land et al., applicants, v. Claude S. Brinegar,
Secretary of Transportation et al. The motions of the State of Hawaii
and of Kalihi-Palama Community Council et al. to vacate the stay
and injunction entered by Mr. Justice Douglas on November 7, 1973,
are granted. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1973

(Journal)
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–241. Chicago Mercantile Exchange, petitioner, v. Darryl
B. Deaktor et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Stewart dissents.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-110. Alphonse J. Zukowski, appellant, v. State Bar
Grievance Board, State Bar of Michigan. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-165. Margaret Botens et al., appellants, v. Milton Aronauer
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-453. Robert A. Manning, appellant, v. John Joyce Gilligan,
Governor of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-483. James Sturgis et al., appellants, v. Washington et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Washington. Motion to dispense with printing jurisdictional
statement granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.

213
No. 73-498. Stanley C. Burger et al., appellants, v. Thomas L.

No. 73-534. Human Rights Party of Washtenaw County et al.,

Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-545. Chester Spatt, appellant, v. New York et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
New York. Judgment affirmed.

No. 73-5481. Geneva H. Sayles, appellant, v. Matthew F. Mc-

Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

affirmed.

Circuit granted. The motion of Heck's, Inc., for leave to intervene is

No. 73-439. Lehman Brothers, petitioner, v. Jacob Schein et al.;
No. 73-440. Benjamin Simon, petitioner, v. Jacob Schein and
Marvin H. Schein; and
No. 73-495. Investors Diversified Services, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Jacob Schein et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted. Cases
consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument limited
to the following question:
"Did the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit err in not
certifying the question of Florida law to the Florida Supreme Court
pursuant to Florida's certification procedure? Fla. Stat. Ann. Sec.
25.032 (1961), Fla. App. Rules, R. 4.61 (1967)."
No. 73-466. William E. Arnold Company, petitioner, v. Carpen-
ters District Council of Jacksonville and Vicinity, etc., et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida granted. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in the case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 73-473. Daniel T. Taylor, III, petitioner, v. John P. Hayes,
Judge, Jefferson Circuit Court, Criminal Branch, Second Division.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky
granted limited to Questions 1, 2, and 3 presented by the petition
which read as follows:



MONDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1973
216
"1. When a trial judge summarily imposes consecutive sentences on
eight counts of contempt aggregating four and one-half years' im-
prisonment, including sentences of one year's imprisonment on two
counts, whether he or the appellate court may subsequently, in order
to defeat the alleged contemnor's right to trial by jury, reduce the sen-
tences so that the sentence on no one count exceeds six months' im-
prisonment and direct that the sentences run concurrently for a total
of six months' imprisonment?
"2. When alleged contempts have been committed by an attorney in
the presence of the trial judge and the trial judge proceeds summarily
to punish for contempt, whether due process requires that the at-
torney be given some opportunity to be heard in defense or mitigation
before he is finally adjudged guilty and sentence is imposed?
"3. Whether, in the circumstances of this case, the trial judge could
impartially sit in judgment on multiple contempt charges against the
petitioner?"
No. 73-5615. Dominick Codispoti and Herbert Langnes, peti-
tioners, v. Pennsylvania. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania, Western District, granted limited to Questions
1 and 2 presented by the petition which read as follows:
"1. Should petitioners receive cumulative sentences for contempt
of court imposed at the end of a trial where the total effective sentence
received must be used rather than the individual sentences in order
to determine the seriousness of the contempt and thereby determine
whether the accused should be afforded the right to a jury trial?
"2. Should the strong possibility of a substantial term of imprison-
ment require that an accused be afforded the right to a jury trial?"
CERTIORARI DENIED
