OPINIONS
No. 72-1148. Hoyt C. Cupp, Superintendent, Oregon State Peni-
tentiary, petitioner, v. Hugh Kyle Naughten. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 72–312. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. David Ware et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part
in the decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 72–1061. Windward Shipping (London) Limited et al., peti-
tioners, v. American Radio Association, AFL-CIO, et al. Argument
concluded by Mr. Howard Schulman for the respondents.

pany. Argued by Mr. Robert J. Hobbs for the petitioner and by
Mr. Thomas J. O'Sullivan for the respondent.

Rhodes et al. Argued by Mr. Michael E. Geltner for the petitioner
and by Mr. Charles E. Brown for the respondents.

Allison Krause, et al., petitioners, v. James Rhodes et al. Argued by

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1973
241
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
OPINION
No. 72–844. E. E. Falk, Individually and as Partner in Drucker
& Falk, et al., petitioners, v. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor,
United States Department of Labor. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Virginia for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
White, and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 72-702. Golden State Bottling Company, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. National Labor Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 72-1176. North Dakota State Board of Pharmacy, petitioner,
v. Snyder's Drug Stores, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of North Dakota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of North Dakota for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-1154. John P. Foley, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Blair & Co.,
Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals to consider whether cause has now become moot.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 72–1035. Julia Rogers, petitioner, v. Leroy Loether et al.
Argument continued by Mr. Robert D. Scott for the respondents and
concluded by Mr. Jack Greenberg for the petitioner.
No. 72-402. United States, appellant, v. General Dynamics Cor-
poration et al. One and one-half hours allowed for oral argument.
Argued by Mr. Daniel M. Friedman for the appellant and by Mr.
Reuben L. Hedlund for the appellees.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1973
243
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders have been certified by the Chief Justices, filed with
the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
_
No. 73-579. State Tax Commission of Arizona et al., appellants, v.
Prudential Insurance Company of America. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Arizona. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
No. 73-621. Union Pacific Railroad Company et al., appellants, v.
The City and County of Denver et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 73-623. Young Lords Party et al., appellants, v. Supreme
Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. Judgment affirmed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-517. Allan G. Kaplan, applicant, v. Continental Can Com-
pany, Inc., et al. The application for a writ of mandamus and for other
relief presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. A-535. Louis Epifania, applicant, v. United States. The appli-
cation for a stay of the execution and enforcement of the judgment of
conviction presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to
the court, is denied.
540-278-7345



MONDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1973
244
No. 72-1490. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Texaco,
Inc., et al.; and
No. 72–1491. Dudley T. Dougherty et al., Co-Executors, Estate of
Mrs. James R. Dougherty, et al., petitioners, v. Texaco, Inc., et al. The
motion of the Independent Petroleum Association of America for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-1598. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Bell
Aerospace Company, Division of Textron, Inc. The motion of the
International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural
Implement Workers of America (UAW) for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-5830. Clover Patterson, appellant, v. George Warner, etc.,
et al. The motion of Cletus B. Hanley to permit Phillip D. Gaujot to
present oral argument, pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. The motion of New York State Trial Lawyers Association for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of
NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted. The motion of California Trial
Lawyers Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is grant-
ed. The motion of Public Citizen and Consumers Union of United
States, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–406. Kevin Burns, Commissioner, State of Iowa, Depart-
ment of Social Services, et al., petitioners, v. Jane Doe etc., et al.; and
No. 73-5650. Jane Doe, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Kevin Burns,
Commissioner, Iowa Department of Social Services, et al. The Solici-
tor General is invited to file a brief in these cases expressing the views
of the United States.
No. 73–615. Ralph Prudhomme, petitioner, v. Al Johnson Con-
struction Company-Massman Construction Company et al. The motion
to dispense with printing the petition is denied with leave to file
printed petition in conformity with Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court
on or before December 27, 1973. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
the motion.

OPINIONS
No. 72–936. United States, petitioner, v. Willie Robinson, Jr. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell in this case and in No. 71-1669,
post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr.
Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.
No. 71-1669. James E. Gustafson, petitioner, v. Florida. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell in this case and
in No. 72-936, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan join.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1973

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-519. Lloyd Turner and Erwin Koorenny, appellants, v.
William A. Egan et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Alaska. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
would postpone the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case
on the merits.
No. 73-569. Ray Dale Petty et al., appellants, v. Roxie McDonald,
Executrix of Estate of Hazel Petty. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73–656. William L. Virden and Norma Virden, dba Chilled
Fresh Fruit Company, appellants, v. James E. Schaffner, etc. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-685. Joseph M. Levine, appellant, v. John R. Busick and
Gilma Giraldo (Busick). Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-583. Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, appel-
lant, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Kentucky. Judgment affirmed.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this appeal.
No. 73–599. Outpost Development Corporation, dba Lydia Feld-
man Methods, appellant, v. United States et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Central District of California.
Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-601. American Trucking Associations, Inc., et al., appel-
lants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the, Western District of Texas. Judgment affirmed.
540-278-73 49



MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1973
261
No. 73–639. Texas-Oklahoma Express, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-658. Garth R. Seehawer et al., appellants, v. Wilbur
Schmidt et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Wisconsin. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-682. Public Utility District No. 2 of Grant County, et al.,
appellants, v. Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Black-
mun would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-202. Donald Thomas Margraf, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Upon the representation of the Solicitor General set forth
in his memorandum for the United States filed November 20, 1973,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
reconsideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
Government.
•
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. _
Bowman Transportation, Inc., et al., applicants, v.
Arkansas-Best Freight System et al. The motion of appellants to
waive Rule 39 as to the preparation of the appendix to the juris-
dictional statement is granted.
No. A-527. District 65, National Council of Distributive Workers
of America, applicant, v. Arthur Eisenberg, Acting Regional Director,
etc. The application for stay of preliminary injunction presented to
Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-533. Chester Bass, applicant, v. Texas. The application for
stay of the execution and enforcement of the mandate of the Court of
Criminal Appeals of Texas presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-544. United States Board of Parole, applicant, v. Hector S.
Amaya. The motion of the respondent to vacate the stay heretofore.
granted by Mr. Justice Powell is denied.
No. A-545. Thomas Justin Millican, Individually and dba Hip
Magazine, applicant, v. United States. The application for stay and
for continuance of bond presented to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant
the application.

No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.

curiae, in support of the petitioners is denied.

tioner, v. Abran Ramirez et al. The motion of the Attorney General of
California to present oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of the
petitioner is granted.

Magnovox Company of Tennessee. The motion of International
Union of Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers, AFL-CIO-CLC,
to present oral argument in support of the petitioner is denied.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. The motion of American Civil Liberties Union for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.

feller, Governor of State of New York, et al.; and
No. 73–219. Thomas J. Sanford et al., appellants, v. Nelson A.
Rockefeller et al. The parties are requested to file supplemental
memoranda addressed to the question of whether these cases are moot
or inappropriate for review at this time.

tioners, v. Daniel T. Spitler, Prosecuting Attorney of Wood County,

MONDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1973
263
No. 73-763. Carl E. Hightower, petitioner, v. Indiana. The mo-
tion to dispense with printing the petitions are denied with
leave to file printed petitions in conformity with Rule 39 of the Rules
of this Court on or before January 15, 1974. Mr. Justice Stewart would
grant the motions. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of the motions in Nos. 73–686
and 73-687.
No. 73-628. Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc., appellant, v. Ben
E. Pittman. Consideration of the jurisdictional statement is deferred
to accord counsel for appellant opportunity to secure a certificate from
the Supreme Court of Mississippi as to whether the judgment herein
was intended to rest on an adequate and independent state ground or
on federal grounds. Charleston Federal Savings & Loan Association
et al. v. Alderson, State Tax Commissioner, 324 U.S. 182, 186 n.1
(1945).

District of California. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.
Motion of appellants for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted

tiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon granted.

OPINIONS
No. 72-397. Bonelli Cattle Company et al., petitioners, v. Arizona
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Arizona
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 72-888. H. Keith Zahn et al., petitioners, v. International
Paper Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 72-1231. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v.
Savair Manufacturing Company. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun
join.
Adjourned until Monday, January 7, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

(Journal)
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1973
274
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-608. Federal Power Commission, applicant, v. Consumer
Federation of America et al. The application to vacate the stay
entered by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred
to the Court, is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from vacating
the stay. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.
☑
540-278--73-51



(Journal)
MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1974
275
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with
the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-360. Arch A. Moore, Jr., Governor of West Virginia,
appellant, v. John H. Kelly, Treasurer of West Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–384. Emmerich Handler and Murray Kleiman, appellants,
v. Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-630. Tower Plaza Investments, Limited, et al., appellants,
v. L. Waldo DeWitt et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-5360. Ronney Ray Newton, appellant, v. Virginia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–386. Jim Sharp, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from the
Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further con-
sideration in light of Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris
Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49 (1973); Kaplan v. California,
413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413
U.S. 123 (1973); United States v. Orito, 413 U.S. 139 (1973); Heller
v. New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413 U.S. 496
(1973); and Alexander v. Virginia, 413 U.S. 836 (1973). Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 73-715. Louie L. Wainwright, Director, Florida Division of
Corrections, appellant, v. Andrew Jackson Mayo. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of ap-
540-278-74—52
F



MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1974
276
pellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consid-
eration in light of Wainwright v. Stone, 414 U.S. 21 (1973).
No. 73–736. Lloyd D. Kister et al., appellants, v. Ohio Board of
Regents et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Ohio. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-5261. Thomas A. Boswell, appellant, v. Alabama. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-200. Roy Splawn, petitioner, v. California. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District; and
No. 73-318. Lawrence Nissinoff et al., petitioners, v. California.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the
Superior Court of California, County of Alameda. Petitions for writs
of certiorari granted, judgments vacated, and cases remanded to the
respective courts for further consideration in light of Miller v. Cali-
fornia, 413 U.S. 15 (1973); Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S.
49 (1973) ; Kaplan v. California, 413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States
v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973); United States v. Orito,
413 U.S. 139 (1973); Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden
v. Kentucky, 413 U.S. 496 (1973); and Alexander v. Virginia, 413
U.S. 836 (1973). Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting
statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-12. In Matter of Disbarment of John T. Isaacson.
It having been reported to this Court that John T. Isaacson, of St.
Louis, State of Missouri, has been disbarred from the practice of law
in all of the Courts of the State of Missouri, and this Court by order
of October 23, 1973, having suspended the said John T. Isaacson from
the practice of law in this Court and directed that a rule issue requir-
ing him to show cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served upon
the respondent and that the time within which to file a return to the
rule has expired;
It is ordered that the said John T. Isaacson be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court.



MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 1974
277
No. D-13. In Matter of Disbarment of Isadore Albert Lehrer.
It having been reported to this Court that Isadore Albert Lehrer,
of Washington, District of Columbia, has been disbarred from the
practice of law in all of the Courts of the District of Columbia, and
this Court by order of October 23, 1973, having suspended the said
Isadore Albert Lehrer from the practice of law in this Court and
directed that a rule issue requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued upon the re-
spondent and that the time within which to file a return to the rule
has expired;
It is ordered that the said Isadore Albert Lehrer be, and he is
hereby, disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his
name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice.
before the Bar of this Court.
No. D-18. In Matter of Disbarment of John J. Stanton.
John J. Stanton, of Boston, Commonwealth of Massachusetts, hav-
ing requested to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is
ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted
to practice before the Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause here-
tofore issued on November 12, 1973, is hereby discharged.
No. A-635. Maurice R. Franks, applicant, v. Max C. Wilson et al.
The application for a stay of the execution and enforcement of the
judgment of the United States District Court for the District of
Colorado presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to
the Court, is denied.

California District Council of Laborers for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.

amicus curiae, is granted.

is granted. The motion of Writers Guild of America et al., for leave
to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of The Authors

granted.

Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.

ern District of Indiana for further proceedings in conformity with

Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.

MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1974
300
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 73–568. Wilbur Schmidt, Director of Wisconsin Department
of Health and Social Services, et al., appellants, v. Alberta Lessard et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern Dis-
trict of Wisconsin. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion per curiam. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
No. 73–573. Denis M. Vachon, appellant, v. New Hampshire.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice White
join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-5337. Violet Lawton Payne, etc., appellant, v. Thomas S.
Fox, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the dismissal of the appeal
and from the denial of certiorari.
No. 73-5776. Jeannittia B. Newton, appellant, v. Lee Burgin et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western District
of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents
from the affirmance.

MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1974
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
301
No. 72–1462. Garrell S. Mullaney et al., petitioners, v. Stillman E.
Wilbur, Jr. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of State v. Lafferty,
A.2d 647 (1973).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
309
No. A-627. Samuel E. Livieri et al., applicants, v. United States
et al. The application for stay of execution and enforcement of judg-
ment of the United States District Court for the District of Connecti-
cut (Civil No. 15741), presented to Mr. Justice Marshall, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-15. In the Matter of the Disbarment of Marshall Howard
Sevin. Marshall Howard Sevin, of Century City, State of California,
having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is
ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys ad-
mitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause
heretofore issued on October 23, 1973, is hereby discharged.
No. 72-1035. Julia Rogers, petitioner, v. Leroy Loether et al. The
motion of petitioner to change name in this case from Julia Rogers
to Julia Rogers Curtis is granted.
No. 72-1570. Robert H. Donnelly, petitioner, v. Benjamin A.
DeChristoforo. The motion of The National Association of Criminal
Defense Lawyers for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 72-1603. Harold J. Cardwell, Warden, petitioner, v. Arthur
Ben Lewis. The motion of respondent for the appointment of counsel
is granted, and it is ordered that Bruce A. Campbell, Esquire, of
Columbus, Ohio, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
No. 73-62. Hubert Wheeler et al., petitioners, v. Anna Barrera
et al. The motion of American Civil Liberties Union et al., for leave
to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted. The motion of the United
States for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in
support of respondents is granted and fifteen additional minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The petitioners are allotted fifteen addi-
tional minutes for oral argument.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. The motion of respondents for additional time for oral argument
is granted and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that pur-
pose. The petitioner is allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral
argument.



MONDAY, JANUARY 14, 1974
302
No. 73–364. Amerind, appellant. v. C. R. Mancari et al.; and
No. 73-773. Mabel McNeill, petitioner, v. Robert Edward Fisher
and Charles J. Fisher, Jr. The motions to dispense with printing the
jurisdictional statement in No. 73-364 and the petition in No. 73–773
are denied with leave to file printed jurisdictional statement and peti-
tion in these cases in conformity with Rule 39 of the Rules of this
Court on or before January 29, 1974.
No. 73-570. Southwire Company et al., petitioners, v. Metal
Equipment Company. The motion of respondent for damages for
delay caused by the is denied PETITION FOR CERTIGRARI
No. 73–899. Joseph P. Moody et al., appellants, v. Albermarle
Paper Company et al. The parties are granted leave and are invited
to file briefs on or before February 13, 1974, in the form specified
by Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court, in response to the question
certified by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit.
No. 73-5284. Douglas Dorszynski, petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of the petitioner for appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Robert H. Friebert, Esquire, of Milwaukee,
Wisconsin, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the
petitioner in this case.
No. 73-5615. Dominick Codispoti and Herbert Langnes, peti-
tioners, v. Pennsylvania. The motion of Robert L. Eberhardt, Esquire,
for leave to present oral argument, pro hac vice, on behalf of the
respondent is granted.

with printing motion to dismiss or affirm denied. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.

on the merits.

(Journal)
MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1974
316
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73-731. Francis Snider et al., petitioners, v. All State Ad-
ministrators, Inc., et al. On motion to dispense with printing petition
for certiorari. Motion to dispense with printing petition denied with
leave to file printed petition in conformity with Rule 39 of the Rules
of this Court within twenty-one days from the entry of this order.
Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-668. Harold T. Fields, appellant, v. Reubin Askew et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas dis-
sents from the dismissal of the appeal. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction.
No. 73-5359. In re Ann Goalen, appellant. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr.
Justice Brennan join.
No. 73-5675. John Brent Tarlton, Jr., appellant, v. Texas. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–930. United States Steel Corporation, petitioner, v. United
Mine Workers of America et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
540-278-74- -61



MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1974
317
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Gateway
Coal Co. v. United Mine Workers of America, 414 U.S. - (1974).
Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the vacation and remand.
No. 72-6155. Anthony Dominic Ciotti, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of United States v. Maze, 414 U.S. — (1974).
-
No. 73–354. Little Art Corporation dba Art 16 Theatre, peti-
tioner, v. Nebraska. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Nebraska. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Nebraska for
further consideration in light of Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15
(1973); Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49 (1973); Kaplan
v. California, 413 U.S. 115 (1973); United States v. 12 200-ft Reels of
Film, 413 U.S. 123 (1973); United States v. Orito, 413 U.S. 139 (1973);
Heller v. New York, 413 U.S. 483 (1973); Roaden v. Kentucky, 413
U.S. 496 (1973); and Alexander v. Virginia, 413 U.S. 836 (1973).
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Douglas.

this Court or, if applicable, file a motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis, with supporting affidavits, pursuant to Rule 53 of the Rules
of this Court, on or before February 11, 1974.

missioner of Internal Revenue;
No. 73-732. Douglas Dale Sutter, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 73-891. Flora Purin, aka Flora Moreira, petitioner, v. United

with leave to file printed petitions in each of these cases in conformity
with Rule 39 of the Rules of this Court on or before February 11, 1974.

Councilman. The motion for leave to proceed on the original record
is granted.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit during the weeks of May 27
and June 3, 1974, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.

MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1974
330
Mr. Solicitor General Bork presented the Honorable William B.
Saxbe, Attorney General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important duties which devolve upon you as the chief law.
officer of the Government, and as an officer of this Court. Your com-
mission will be recorded with the Clerk."
OPINIONS
No. 72-777. Cleveland Board of Education et al., petitioners, v. Jo
Carol LaFleur et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit; and
No. 72-1129. Susan Cohen, petitioner, v. Chesterfield County
School Board et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment in No. 72-777 affirmed.
Judgment in No. 72-1129 reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Douglas
concurs in the result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 72-851. The Oneida Indian Nation of New York State et al.,
petitioners, v. The County of Oneida, New York, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins.
No. 72-5704. Jean Christian and Victor L. Green, appellants, v.
New York State Department of Labor, Division of Employment,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 72-1019. Sea-Land Services, Inc., petitioner, v. Helen Stein
Gaudet, Administratrix of the Estate of Awtrey C. Gaudet, Sr. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dis-
1919. Seu Luned for cobrenapetitioner Helen Stein
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 72–6520. Kinney Kinmon Lau, a minor by and through Mrs.
Kam Wai Lau, his guardian ad litem, et al., petitioners, v. Alan H.



MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1974
331
Nichols et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for the fashioning of appropriate relief.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
concurring in the result with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Blackmun join. Mr. Justice White concurs in the result.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 19, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1974

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-734. Dolph Briscoe, Governor of Texas, et al., applicants,
v. Curtis Graves et al. The motions to vacate the stay heretofore
granted by Mr. Justice Powell are denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
dissents.

540-278-74-63



(Journal) TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1974
333
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–347. Phillips Petroleum Company, petitioner, v. Texaco,
Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of the Northern Natural Gas
Company et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, denied. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas
and Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice White took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–232. Exxon Corporation, appellant, v. Jay M. Preston. Ap-
peal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Ninth Supreme Judi-
cial District. Upon receiving and filing the appellee's waiver of right
to file an opposing brief with his representation that he no longer op-
poses the change of venue of the litigation to Harris County, Texas,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Civil Appeals of
Texas, Ninth Supreme Judicial District, to consider whether the venue
issue has become moot. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 73-766. Raymond E. Ledford et al., appellants, v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–812. Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission, appellant,
v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Middle District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed.
(JOURNAL)

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1974
334
No. 73-961. George C. Wallace, as Governor of the State of Ala-
bama, et al., appellants, v. M. O. Sims et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 73-897. Anna A. Phelps, appellant. v. Stephen J. Covey, Ref-
eree in Bankruptcy. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 73-940. Peter D. Bogart, appellant, v. State Bar of California.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-956. Pittsburgh Coal Company, Division of Consolidation
Coal Company, appellant, v. Pennsylvania; and
No. 73–957. Harmar Coal Company, appellant, v. Pennsylvania.
Appeals from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District.
The appeals are dismissed for want of substantial federal questions.
No. 73-993. Anna A. Phelps, appellant, v. Commissioners of the
Supreme Court of Illinois et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73–5879. David Preston Calaway, appellant, v. West Virginia.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–6004. Walter Linville Abercrombie, appellant, v. Ohio. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Clermont County. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–929. Del Paso Recreation and Park District et al., appel-
lants, v. Board of Supervisors of the County of Sacramento et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 73-951. Neeta Webb, appellant, v. Robert E. Nolan. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun
would grant certiorari.
No. 73-1005. Charles O. Ross, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case
for oral argument.



TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1974
335
No. 73–1007. Lawrence Franklin et al., appellants, v. Stanley W.
Krause, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question..
Mr. Justice Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set case
for oral argument.
No. 73-5705. Charles A. DunLeavay, appellant, v. Charles Ten-
ney, United States District Judge, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–285. Robert A. Noreikis et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Upon the representation of the Solicitor
General as set forth in his memorandum for the United States filed
January 30, 1974, petition for writ of certiorari as to petitioner George
Hibma granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for recon-
sideration in light of the position presently asserted by the govern-
ment. Petition for writ of certiorari as to Robert A. Noreikis and
Robert Rothrock denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-664. Maurice A. Gellis, applicant, v. City of Savannah et al.
The application for vacation of the order of the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Georgia (Civil Action No. 3031)
dated January 7, 1974, dismissing the case for lack of prosecution is
denied. The application for stay, heretofore denied by Mr. Justice
Powell and now presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. A-712. New York, on behalf of New York, Bronx and Kings
Counties, etc., applicant, v. United States et al. The application for a
stay of the order of the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia, dated January 10, 1974, presented to the Chief Justice and
by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-742. Harris County Commissioners Court et al., applicants,
v. Richard E. Moore et al. The motion of the respondents to vacate the
stay order heretofore granted by Mr. Justice Powell on February 4,
1974, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would vacate the stay.
No. A-752. Harold W. Brobeck, applicant, v. United States et al.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-760. Tonia Ackerman et al., applicant, v. Andrew W. Bogue.
The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.

ordered that Edmund Allen Rosner of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

of Ohio is denied. The motion of the Chamber of Commerce of the

Judicial Circuit of Florida, petitioner, v. Robert Pugh et al. The mo-

is allotted for that purpose. The respondents are allotted an additional
fifteen minutes for oral argument.

motion for the appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered
that Kenneth M. Mogill, Esquire, of Detroit, Michigan be, and he is
hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case
and to argue pro hac vice.

tion noted and case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 73-759.
No. 73-762. Carol Maureen Sosna, etc., appellant, v. Iowa et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Iowa. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. In addition to
the questions presented in the jurisdictional statement, the parties are
requested to address themselves to the question of whether the United
States District Court should have proceed to the merits of the con-
stitutional issue presented in light of Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S.
37 (1971) and related cases.

OPINIONS
371
No. 72-403. Arthur F. Sampson, Administrator, General Serv-
ices Administration, et al., petitioners, v. Jeanne M. Murray. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 72–1061. Windward Shipping (London) Limited, et al., peti-
tioners, v. American Radio Association, AFL-CIO, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth Supreme
Judicial District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth Supreme Judicial District,
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 72-5847. Harrell Alexander Sr., petitioner, v. Gardner-Den-
ver Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 72-822. The Renegotiation Board, petitioner, v. Bannercraft
Clothing Company, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
with whom Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice
Powell concur.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 72–6041. Dave Pernell, petitioner, v. Southall Realty. Argued
by Mr. Norman C. Barnett for the petitioner and by Mr. Herman
Miller for the respondent.
No. 72-1490. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Texaco,
Inc., et al; and
No. 72-1491. Dudley T. Dougherty et al., Co-Executors, Estate of
Mrs. James R. Dougherty, et al., petitioners, v. Texaco, Inc., et al.
Argued by Mr. Mark L. Evans for the petitioner in No. 72-1490, by
Mr. Ben F. Vaughan, III, for the petitioners in No. 72-1491, and
by Mr. Christopher T. Boland and by Mr. Peter H. Schiff for the re-
spondents in both cases.



TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1974
372
No. 72-1597. Ulysses Vernon Beasley et al., petitioners, v. Food
Fair of North Carolina, Inc., et al. Argued by Mr. Larry L. Eubanks
for the petitioners and by Mr. Ralph Madison Stockton, Jr., for the
respondents.
No. 72–1660. Stanley Blackledge, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Jimmy Seth Perry. Argued by Mr. Richard N. League for the peti-
tioners and by Mr. James E. Keenan for the respondent.
No. 73–191. Village of Belle Terre et al., appellants, v. Bruce
Boraas et al. Argued commenced by Mr. Bernard E. Gegan for the
appellants.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1974
375
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–428. United States, petitioner, v. Norbert Nisan Kahan. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York for reinstatement of the judg-
ment of conviction. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan concurs. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-987. Richard E. Guggenheim, Director, Department of
Liquor Control, State of Ohio, et al., appellants, v. George Peto, Jr.,
dba Loop Carry Out. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Ohio. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 73-1087. Helen C. Koscherak, etc., et al., appellants, v. Kurt
R. Schmeller, President, Queensborough Community College, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-6036. Albert Fischler, appellant, v. ITT Federal Electric
Corp. et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-741. Donn E. Davison, applicant, v. Florida. The applica-
tion for a stay of the mandate of the Supreme Court of Florida pre-
540-278-74-70



MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1974
376
sented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan would grant.
the stay.
No. A-793. George P. Baker et al., Trustees of Penn Central
Transportation Company, applicants, v. United States et al. The appli-
cation for stay presented to Mr. Justice Brennan, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. D-21. In Matter of Disbarment of George Gordon Liddy.
Order of Disbarment entered.
No. 72-942. Robert Hainsworth, appellant, v. Mark White, Jr.,
Secretary of State of Texas. The motion of appellant for leave to file a
supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 72-1713. Secretary of the Navy, appellant, v. Mark Avrech.
Counsel for the parties are directed to file within 21 days supple-
mental briefs on the issues of the jurisdiction of the District Court and
on exhaustion of remedies. These briefs may be typewritten.
No. 72-6160. Lawrence Mitchell, petitioner, v. W. T. Grant Com-
pany. The motion of the State of Louisiana for leave to file a brief on
the merits after argument is granted.
No. 73–235. Marco DeFunis et al., petitioners, v. Charles Ode-
gaard, President of the University of Washington, et al. The motion
of the National Association of Manufacturers of the United States for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae. is denied. The motion of the Com-
mittee on Academic Nondiscrimination and Integrity for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73-300. William B. Saxbe, Attorney General, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Robert Bustos et al.; and
No. 73-480. Cristobal Cardona et al., petitioners, v. William B.
Saxbe, Attorney General, et al. The motion of the California Farm
Bureau Federation et al., for leave to participate in oral argument, as
amici curiae, is denied.
No. 73-434. William G. Milliken, Governor of Michigan, et al.,
petitioners v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother
and next friend, Verda Bradley, et al.;
No. 73-435. Allen Park Public Schools et al., petitioners, v.
Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next
friend, Verda Bradley et al.; and
No. 73-436. The Grosse Pointe Public School System, petitioner,
v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next
friend, Verda Bradley, et al. The motion of respondents Board of Edu-
cation for the School District of the City of Detroit et al., for leave to
participate in oral argument is denied.
No. 73–437. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Federal Power
Commission;



MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1974
377
No. 73-457. Public Service Commission of the State of New York,
petitioner, v. Federal Power Commission; and
No. 73–464. Municipal Distributors Group, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission. The motion of Shell Oil Company to recuse Mr.
Justice William O. Douglas is denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73–482. Michigan, petitioner, v. Thomas W. Tucker. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment, as amicus curiae, is granted and a total of fifteen minutes is al-
lotted for that purpose. The respondent is allotted an additional fifteen
minutes for oral argument.
No. 73-507. William L. Hamling et al., petitioners, v. United
States. The motion of petitioners for additional time for oral argu-
ment is denied.
No. 73–679. Charles Wolff, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Robert O.
McDonnell, etc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is granted and a total of
fifteen minutes is allotted for that purpose. The respondent is allotted
an additional fifteen minutes for oral argument.
No. 73-1003. National Indian Youth Council et al., petitioners,
v. Louis R. Bruce et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied without prejudice to named individuals to
file appropriate affidavits in forma pauperis. See 28 U.S.C. § 1915;
Rule 53, Rules of the Supreme Court of the United States; and Pothier
v. Rodman, 261 U.S. 307, 309 (1923).
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 73-364. Amerind, appellant, v. C. R. Mancari et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of New Mexico.
Motion of appellee Mancari for leave to proceed in forma pauperis in
this case and in No. 73-362 is granted. The motion as to all other appel-
lees in this case and in No. 73-362 is denied. In this case probably
jurisdiction noted. Case consolidated with No. 73-362 and a total of
one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 73-858. Alfredo Gonzalez, individually and on behalf of all
others similarly situated, appellant, v. Automatic Employees Credit
Union et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois. In this case further consideration of the
question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the
merits.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73–748. American Radio Association, AFL-CIO, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Mobile Steamship Association, Inc., et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama granted.



MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1974
378
No. 73-1018. United States, petitioner, v. Martin Dewalt Mazurie
et al. Motion of National Tribal Chairmen's Association for leave to
file brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of the Shoshone Indian
Tribe et al. for leave to file brief, as amici curiae, granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit granted.

denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Powell

this petition.

REHEARINGS DENIED
382
No. 72-1040. Communist Party of Indiana et al., appellants, v.

petitioners, v. United States;
No. 73-5308. Ronald Everett Schneider, petitioner, v. California;
No. 73-5550. Rickey Lee Miller, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 73-5712. Manuel Joe Chavez, petitioner, v. D. J. McCarthy,
Warden; and
No. 73–5781. Marvin Louis Madden, petitioner, v. Circuit Court
for Dodge County et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 72-1289. National Railroad Passenger Corporation et al.,
petitioners, v. National Association of Railroad Passengers. Petition
for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this petition.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Justice
Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit during the period of March 18, 1974,
to March 22, 1974, and for such additional time as may be required to
complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a), is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
§ 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 4, 1974, until
Monday, March 18, 1974.

Walter J. Smith, Jr.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73–190. Isadore H. Bellis, petitioner, v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Leonard Sarner for the petitioner and by Mr. Lawrence G.
Wallace for the respondent.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. One and one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by
Mr. Aaron M. Fine for the petitioner and by Mr. Devereux Milburn
and Mr. William Eldred Jackson for the respondents.
No. 72-6902. Lonnie Gooding, petitioner, v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Herbert A. Rosenthal for the petitioner and by Mr. Andrew L.
Frey for the respondent.
No. 73–78. Mel Kahn, etc., appellant, v. Robert L. Shevin et al.
Argument commenced by Mrs. Ruth Bader Ginsburg for the appellant.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.

Movant
Applicant
City and State
Movant
William Lee Foreman, Jr.
Chicago, Ill.
Mrs. Jewel R.
LaFontant.
OPINIONS
No. 48 Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of Arkan-
sas. On Bill of Complaint. Decree entered. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmum. Dissenting Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-847. Memorial Hospital et al., appellants, v. Maricopa
ช.
County et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Arizona for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Blackmun concur in the result. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 72-5830. Clover Patterson, appellant, v. George Warner, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of West Virginia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Southern District of West
Virginia for reconsideration in the light of State ex rel. Reece v.
Gies W. Va. . 198 S. E. 2d 211 (1973). Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-78. Mel Kahn, etc., appellant, v. Robert L. Shevin et al.
Argument continued by Mr. Sydney H. McKenzie, III, for the ap-
pellees and concluded by Mrs. Ruth Bader Gingsburg for the
appellant.
No. 72-1513. Con F. Shea, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Ascension
Vialpando, etc. Argued by Mr. Douglas D. Doane for the petitioners,
540-278-74- -72



TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1974
390
by Mr. Tom W. Armour for the respondents, and by Mr. Charles B.
Lennahan for the petitioners.
No. 72-1454. Joseph Anthony Davis, petitioner, v. United States.
Argued by Mr. Marvin M. Karpatkin for the petitioner and by Mr.
Edmund W. Kitch for the respondent.
No. 73–235. Marco DeFunis et al., petitioners, v. Charles Ode-
gaard, President of the University of Washington, et al. Argued by
Mr. Josef Diamond for the petitioners and by Mr. Slade Gorton for
the respondents.
No. 73-328. Harry J. Lehman, petitioner, v. City of Shaker
Heights et al. Argument commenced by Mr. Leonard J. Schwartz
for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1974
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Movant
Richard Powers Condit
Bloomfield Hills,
Douglas H. West.
Mich.
Gerald M. Hilby
Redondo Beach,
Danny Julian
Calif.
Boggs.
OPINIONS
No. 72–1637. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The
Magnavox Company of Tennessee. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 72-5794. Joshaway Davis, petitioner, v. Alaska. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alaska. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alaska for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joins.
No. 72-1557. Alvis G. Speight, t/a Harem Book Store, et al.,
appellants v. Lewis R. Slaton, etc., et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia for reconsideration in light of the deci-
sion of the Georgia Supreme Court in Sanders v. Georgia, No. 28352,
January 28, 1974. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger.
540-278-74-73



1
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1974
ORAL ARGUMENT
392
No. 73-328. Harry J. Lehman, petitioner, v. City of Shaker
Heights et al. Argument continued by Mr. Leonard J. Schwartz for
the petitioner and concluded by Mr. Paul R. Donaldson for the
respondents.
No. 73-434. William G. Milliken, Governor of Michigan, et al.,
petitioners v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother
and next friend, Verda Bradley, et al.;
No. 73-435. Allen Park Public Schools et al., petitioners, v. Ronald
Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next friend, Verda
Bradley, et al.; and
No. 73-436. The Grosse Pointe Public School System, petitioner.
v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next
friend, Verda Bradley, et al. One hour and forty-five minutes allowed
for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Frank J. Kelley for the petitioners
in No. 73-434, and by Mr. William M. Saxton for the petitioners in
Nos. 73-435 and 73-436, and by Mr. Solicitor General Robert H. Bork
for the United States, as amicus curiae by special leave of Court, and
by Mr. J. Harold Flannery and Mr. Nathaniel R. Jones for the
respondents in all three cases.
No. 73–263. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v.
Idaho Power Company. Argued by Mr. Keith A. Jones for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Frank Norton Kern for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, March 4, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1974
393
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 72–6023. Coraetta Bias, appellant, v. Joe Gies, etc., et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of West Virginia. Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of West Vir-
ginia for reconsideration in light of Patterson v. Warner, 415 U.S. —
(1974) and State ex rel. Reece v. Gies, W. Va. -, 198 S. E. 2d
211 (1973).
-
No. 73–298. Ramon G. Vela et al., appellants, v. Raymond W.
Vowell et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Texas. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed
further herein in pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 73-1083. Bernice R. Bennett, Administratrix of the Estate of
Wilbur Leon Hardin, appellant, v. Edward Geeler et al. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-6116. Ela Mas, etc., appellant, v. Abe Lavine, Commis-
sioner of New York State Department of Social Services, et al. Appeal
from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Sec-
ond Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 73-1108. Gregory Panko, appellant, v. Joseph M. Donovan
et al. Appeal from the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
540-278-74--74



MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1974
394
No. 73-6081. Peter Butler, appellant, v. Malcolm Wilson, Gov-
ernor of New York, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 72-1603. Harold J. Cardwell, Warden, petitioner, v. Arthur
Ben Lewis. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, in support of petitioner is granted
and fifteen minutes are allotted for that purpose. The respondent is
allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 73-434. William G. Milliken, Governor of Michigan, et al.,
petitioners, v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother
and next friend, Verda Bradley, et al.;
No. 73-435. Allen Park Public Schools et al., petitioners, v.
Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next friend,
Verda Bradley, et al.; and
No. 73-436. The Grosse Pointe Public School System, petitioner,
v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next
friend, Verda Bradley, et al. The motion of Inter-Faith Centers
for Racial Justice, Inc., for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae, is
granted. The motion of National Suburban League, Ltd., for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 73-434, is granted.
No. 73–557. Billy Jenkins, appellant, v. Georgia. The motion of
the Directors Guild of America, Inc., for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–604. Donald C. Cass, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 73–5661. Francis A. Adams et al., petitioners, v. Secretary of
the Navy et al. The motion of petitioners in No. 73-5661 for divided
argument is granted and it is ordered that fifteen minutes be allotted
petitioner in No. 73–604 and fifteen minutes be allotted to petitioners in
No. 73–5661 for oral argument in these consolidated cases.
No. 73-631. Howard Johnson Company, Inc., petitioner, v. Detroit
Local Joint Executive Board, Hotel and Restaurant Employees and
Bartenders International Union, AFL-CIO. The motion of the Cham-
ber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–679. Charles Wolff, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Robert O.
McDonnell, etc. The motion of the Attorney General of California
for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73–690. Air Pollution Variance Board of the State of Colo-
rado, petitioner, v. Western Alfalfa Corporation. The motion of the



MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1974
395
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, in support of petitioner is granted and fifteen minutes are al-
lotted for that purpose. The respondent is allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 73-786. Fred R. Ross and North Carolina, petitioners, v.
Claude Franklin Moffitt. The motion of the Commonwealth of Vir-
ginia for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 73-1016. John Lascaris, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al.; and
No. 73-1095. Abe Lavine, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
No. 73-1221. Continental Casualty Co., petitioner, v. Norman
Ward. The application for stay of execution of the judgment of the
Supreme Court of Ohio and for approval of supersedeas bond pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. 73-5265. Henry A. Kokoszka, petitioner, v. Richard Belford,
Trustee, etc. Benjamin R. Civiletti, Esquire, of Baltimore, Maryland,
a member of the Bar of this Court, is invited to brief and argue this
case, as amicus curiae, in support of the judgment below.
No. 73-5412. John R. Dillard and Willie Williams, etc., appel-
lants, v. Industrial Commission of Virginia et al. The motion of ap-
pellee Aetna Casualty and Surety Company for divided argument is
granted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73–1106. William Cousins et al., petitioners, v. Paul T.
Wigoda et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District, granted.
No. 73-1265. William B. Saxbe, Attorney General of the United
States, et al., petitioners, ". The Washington Post et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit granted. The time for filing appendix and
briefs accelerated so that this case may be argued in tandem with con-
solidated cases Nos. 73-754 and 73-918. A total of two hours allotted
for argument for all three cases.
No. 73-5768. Frank Xavier Francisco, petitioner, v. J. S. Gath-
right, Superintendent, Bland Correctional Farm. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.

No. 73-1097. Electronics Corporation of America, petitioner, v.
Honeywell, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied. The Chief Justice and
Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision
of this petition.

man, etc., et al. Motion to strike respondents' memorandum and for
other relief denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 73-5872. Carl Caver, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 73-5888. Welton Van Hook, petitioner, v. United States Dis-
trict Court, Southern District of California, etc.; and
No. 73-6213. Marion J. Jones, Jr., petitioner, v. Alabama. Motions
for leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus denied.

OPINIONS
