James L. Wosepka
No. 72-1566. Granny Goose Foods, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Brotherhood of Teamsters & Auto Truck Drivers, Local No. 70 of
Alameda County, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in the
judgment with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice Powell join.



MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1974
403
No. 72–1628. Teleprompter Corporation et al., Petitioners, v.
Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., et al.; and
No. 72-1633. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, . Teleprompter Corporation et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed in part and reversed in part and cases remanded to the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York with di-
rections to reinstate its judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurs. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 72-1297. Donald E. Johnson, Administrator of Veterans'
Affairs, et al., appellants, v. William Robert Robison, etc. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Massachusetts for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-700. Henry Hernandez et al., petitioners, v. Veterans'
Administration et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Mr. Justice Douglas concurs in the result for the reasons stated in his
dissenting opinion in Johnson v. Robison, ante.
No. 72-948. National Cable Television Association, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. United States and Federal Communications Commission. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall,
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins, dissenting in this case and
concurring in the result in No. 72–1162, post. Mr. Justice Blackmun
and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 72-1162. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. New
England Power Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall, with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins, concurring in
the result in this case and dissenting in No. 72–948, ante.
Adjourned until Monday, March 18, 1974, at 10 o'clock.







(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
404
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73-5684. Joseph DeMarco, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to remand
case to the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Illinois for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Powell join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-586. John McMullan et al., appellants, v. Helene Wohlge-
muth et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Mid-
dle District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-1114. Roger F. Winchester, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of Cali-
fornia, County of San Diego. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 73-1140. William Kyser, appellant, v. The Board of Elections
of the County of Cuyahoga, Ohio, and Ted W. Brown, Secretary of
State of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–6161. Willie S. Martinez, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-729. The Corporation Commission of the State of Okla-
homa et al., appellants, v. Federal Power Commission et al. Appeal
540-278-74-76



MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
405
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell
join.
No. 73-1080. Grace Holt et al., appellants, v. Henry G. Yonce,
Chairman of South Carolina Public Service Commission, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of South Caro-
lina. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from the sum-
mary affirmance.
No. 73–5972. Justa Ramirez et al., appellants, v. Caspar W. Wein-
berger, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 73-6133. Lewis Clayton, appellant, v. Walter L. Couse Com-
pany et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–752. John Sherman Miles, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of United States v. Maze, 414 U.S. (1974).
Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Black-
mun would affirm judgment.
-
No. 73-5595. Denver Gene Richardson, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Central
District of California so that the judgment of conviction may be
vacated as suggested by the government in the memorandum filed
February 25, 1974.
No. 73-5717. Raymond L. Reese, petitioner, v. U.S. Board of
Parole et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Upon the representation of the Solicitor General set forth in
his memorandum for the United States filed February 20, 1974, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
government.



MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
406
No. 73-5761. Leon Osher, petitioner, v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
United States v. Maze, 414 U.S.- (1974).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-746. Charles Harold Smith, applicant, v. United States.
The application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him
referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-847. Alphonse Persico, applicant, v. United States. The
application for bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-23. In the Matter of Disbarment of Clifford Taylor Lee. It
is ordered that Clifford Taylor Lee of Washington, District of Colum-
bia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92, October Term, 1970. Edgar D. Whitcomb, Governor of the
State of Indiana, appellant, v. Patrick Chavis et al. The motions for
modification of costs and to retax costs are denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant the motion to retax costs.
No. 73–29. Corning Glass Works, petitioner, v. Peter J. Brennan,
Secretary of Labor, United States Department of Labor; and
No. 73-695. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Corning Glass Works. The motion of the American Civil Liberties
Union et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 73-38. United States, appellant, v. Marine Bancorporation,
Inc., et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional time
for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are
allotted for that purpose. The motion of the Comptroller of the
Currency for additional time for oral argument is granted and the
appellees are allotted fifteen additional minutes for that purpose.
No. 73-362. Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, et al.,
appellants, v. C. R. Mancari et al.; and
No. 73-364. Amerind, appellant, v. C. R. Mancari et al. The mo-
tion of the Montana Inter-Tribal Policy Board et al., for leave to
file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 73–370. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Food
Store Employees Union, Local 347, etc. The motion of the Chamber
of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a brief, as amicus



MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
407
curiae, in support of Heck's, Inc., is denied. The motion of Heck's,
Inc. for additional time for oral argument or in the alternative for
divided argument is denied.
No. 73–507. William L. Hamling et al., petitioners, v. United
States. The renewed motion of petitioners for additional time for oral
argument is denied. The alternative request for divided argument is
granted.
No. 73-556. Florida Power & Light Co., petitioner, v. Interna-
tional Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 641, 622, 759, 820,
and 1263, et al.; and
No. 73–795. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Inter-
national Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL-CIO, et al. The
motion of the Solicitor General for additional time for oral argument
is granted and the petitioners are allotted fifteen additional minutes
for that purpose. The respondents are allotted fifteen additional min-
utes for oral argument.
No. 73-640. Dwight Geduldig, etc., appellant, v. Carolyn Aiello
et al. The motion of the Physicians Forum for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, is granted.
No. 73–679. Charles Wolff, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Robert O.
McDonnell, etc. The motion of respondent for the appointment of
counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Douglas F. Duchek, Esquire,
of Lincoln, Nebraska, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve as coun-
sel for the respondent in this case. The motion of respondent that the
said Douglas F. Duchek be granted leave to present oral argument,
pro hac vice, is granted.
No. 73-767. United States, appellant, v. The Connecticut National
Bank et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for additional time
for oral argument is granted and fifteen additional minutes are allotted
for the purpose. The motion of the Comptroller of the Currency for
additional time for oral argument is granted and the appellees are
allotted fifteen additional minutes for that purpose.
No. 73-841. Cale J. Holder, United States District Judge for the
Southern District of Indiana, petitioner, v. Arthur Banks. The mo-
tion of respondent to supplement the record and to defer oral argu-
ment is denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 73-5280. Prince Eric Fuller, petitioner, v. Oregon. The mo-
tion of the National Legal Aid and Defender Association for leave to
dispense with printing their amicus curiae brief is denied.
No. 73-6142. Harland L. Radue, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for stay and bail presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.

Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United State Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice White would grant certiorari.

of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Phila-
delphia District, denied.

Ward. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio
denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
417
No. 73-1125. Admiral-Merchants Motor Freight, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Container Corporation of America et al. Motion to defer
consideration denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 73-1159. Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., petitioner, v. David Pope
Hood. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant in light of the important First and Fourteenth Amendment
questions that are raised. See 486 F. 2d 25, 28-30 with which views
Mr. Justice Douglas disagrees.
No. 73-5828. John Henry Pernell, petitioner, v. James H. Rose,
Warden, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would grant, vacate, and remand on the grounds of mootness.
No. 73-6124. Alfred McKinley, petitioner, v. Review Board of
the Indiana Employment Security Division et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Indiana denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would deny because the petition was filed out of time.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 73-6240. Vasco X. Howard, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Division of Corrections, et al. Motion for
leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.

ORDERS
424
ORDERED:
1. That the rules and forms as approved by the Judicial Conference
of the United States and annexed hereto, to be known as the Chap-
ter XI Rules and Official Chapter XI Forms, be, and they hereby
are, prescribed pursuant to Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code,
to govern the forms of process, writs, pleadings and motions and the
practice and procedure under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act,
in the proceedings and to the extent set forth therein, in the United
States district courts, the District Court for the District of the Canal
Zone, and the District Courts of Guam and the Virgin Islands.
2. That the aforementioned Chapter XI Rules and Official Chap-
ter XI Forms shall take effect on July 1, 1974, and shall be applicable
to proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the opinion
of the court their application in a particular proceeding then pending
would not be feasible or would work injustice, in which event the
former procedure applies.
3. That General Order in Bankruptcy 48 and Official Forms in
Bankruptcy 48 to 52 inclusive, heretofore prescribed by this Court
be, and they hereby are, abrogated, effective July 1, 1974.
4. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the aforementioned new Chapter XI Rules and Official
Chapter XI Forms to the Congress in accordance with the provisions
of Title 28, U. S. C. § 2075.
Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.
ORDERED:
1. That subdivision 14 of Official Bankruptcy Form 7 prescribed
by this Court by Order entered April 24, 1973, be, and it hereby is,
amended, effective July 1, 1974, to read as follows:
"14. Losses.
"a. Have you suffered any losses from fire, theft, or gambling
during the year immediately preceding the filing of the original



MONDAY, MARCH 18, 1974
425
petition herein? (If so, give particulars, including dates, names,
and places, and the amounts of money or value and general descrip-
tion of property lost.)
"b. Was the loss covered in whole or part by insurance? (If so,
give particulars.)
"15. Payments or transfers to attorneys.
"a. Have you consulted an attorney during the year immediately
preceding or since the filing of the original petition herein? (Give
date, name, and address.)
"b. Have you during the year immediately preceding or since
the filing of the original petition herein paid any money or trans-
ferred any property to the attorney or to any other person on his
behalf? (If so, give particulars, including amount paid or value
of property transferred and date of payment or transfer.)
"c. Have you, either during the year immediately preceding or
since the filing of the original petition herein, agreed to pay any
money or transfer any property to an attorney at law, or to any
other person on his behalf? (If so, give particulars, including
amount and terms of obligation.)"
2. That subdivision (a) of Rule 41 and the first paragraph of
Rule 50 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended, effective July 1, 1974, to read as follows:
"Rule 41. Search and Seizure.
"(a) Authority to Issue Warrant. A search warrant authorized
by this rule may be issued by a federal magistrate or a judge
of a state court of record within the district wherein the property
is located, upon request of a federal law enforcement officer or an
attorney for the government.
"Rule 50. Calendars; Plan for Prompt Disposition.
"(a) Calendars. The district courts may provide for placing
criminal proceedings upon appropriate calendars. Preference
shall be given to criminal proceedings as far as practicable."
3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and he hereby is, authorized to
transmit the foregoing amendments to Official Bankruptcy Form 7
and Rules 41 and 50 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to
the Congress in accordance with Title 28 U. S. C. § 2075 and Title 18,
U.S. C. § 3771.

Bartenders International Union, AFL-CIO. Argument commenced.
by Mr. James D. Tracy for the petitioner and continued by Mr.
Laurence Gold for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

one-half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. L. Brooks

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1974
430
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–5925. Terry Dean Eaton, petitioner, v. City of Tulsa. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Oklahoma. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom The Chief Justice and Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-949. Joseph F. McIlvaine, appellant, v. Pennsylvania.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 73-1139. Maurice R. Franks, appellant, v. Max C. Wilson et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas dissents from the dismissal of the appeal.
No. 73-6031. Howard Kaplan, appellant, v. Henriette Kaplan.
Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, Second Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 72-5847. Harrell Alexander, Sr., petitioner, v. Gardner-
Denver Company. The motion of the petitioner for attorneys fees
540-278-74– -81



MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1974
431
as part of taxable costs is denied as not appropriate for consideration
by this Court. Mr. Justice Douglas would refer the motion to the
District Court for a hearing on retaxing costs.
No. 73–191. Village of Belle Terre et al., appellants, v. Bruce
Boraas et al. The motion of New Communities, Inc., for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, after argument, is denied.
No. 73-437. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Federal Power
Commission;
No. 73-457. Public Service Commission of the State of New York,
petitioner, v. Federal Power Commission; and
No. 73-464. Municipal Distributors Group, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided
argument is granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 73-482. Michigan, petitioner, v. Thomas W. Tucker. The mo-
tion of Women Lawyers Association of Michigan for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 73-781. Fritz Scherk, petitioner, v. Alberto-Culver Company.
The motion of the American Arbitration Association for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 73-628. Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc., appellant, v. Ben E.
Pittman. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. In this case
further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the
hearing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1012. Gulf Oil Corporation et al., petitioners, v. Copp
Paving Company, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted limited
to question 1 (a), (b), and (c) presented in the petition which reads
as follows:
"1. With respect to a commodity which is not only made and sold
in one state alone but is only salable and usable in that state, does
the fact that it is used in an instrumentality of commerce such as a
highway supply the necessary requirements, by itself and as a matter
of law
(a) Of the anti-discrimination clause of the Robinson-Patman Act
that the discriminatory sale be by a 'person engaged in commerce, in
the course of such commerce,' that 'either or any of the purchases
involved *** [be] in commerce,' and that the 'effect ***
may be



MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1974
432
substantially to lessen competition or tend to create a monopoly in
any line of commerce?"
(b) Of Section 3 of the Clayton Act that the tying conduct be that
of a 'person engaged in commerce, in the course of such commerce',
and that 'the effect ***
may be to substantially lessen competition
or tend to create a monopoly in any line of commerce?"
(c) Of Section 7 of the Clayton Act that the acquisition by a
'corporation engaged in commerce' be of a corporation 'engaged also
in commerce,' and that 'the effect *** may be substantially to lessen
competition, or tend to create a monopoly,' where the acquired corpo-
ration sold nothing in commerce and the product it made did not enter
commerce?"
CERTIORARI DENIED

OPINIONS
No. 72-1410. Joel Edelman, Director of Illinois Department of
Public Aid, etc., petitioner, v. John Jordan et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 72-1254. Joseph Smith, Sheriff of Worcester County, appel-
lant, v. Valarie Goguen. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.



1
MONDAY, MARCH 25, 1974
443
No. 72-1264. Mayor of the City of Philadelphia, et al., petitioners,
v. Educational Equality League, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join and with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins in part II.
No. 72-6476. Cynthia Hagans et al., petitioners, v. Abe Lavine,
Commissioner of New York State Department of Social Services,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Powell join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73–29. Corning Glass Works, petitioner, v. Peter J. Brennan,
Secretary of Labor, United States Department of Labor; and
No. 73–695. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Corning Glass Works. Argued by Mr. Scott F. Zimmerman for the
petitioner in No. 73-29 and for the respondent in No. 73-695 and by
Mr. Allan A. Tuttle for the respondent in No. 73-29 and for the peti-
tioner in No. 73–695.
No. 73–477. Richard E. Gerstein, State Attorney for Eleventh
Judicial Circuit of Florida, petitioner, v. Robert Pugh et al. One
and one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Leonard
R. Mellon for the petitioner and by Mr. Raymond L. Marky for the
State of Florida, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by
Mr. Bruce S. Rogow for the respondents.
No. 73-5615. Dominick Codispoti and Herbert Langnes, peti-
tioners, v. Pennsylvania. Argued by Mr. John J. Dean for the peti-
tioners and by Mr. Robert L. Eberhardt for the respondent, pro hac
vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 73–593. Central Tablet Manufacturing Co., petitioner, v.
United States. Argument commenced by Mr. Larry H. Snyder for the
petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 72-1076. William C. Huddleston, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-812. Thomas Tone Storer et al., appellants, v. Edmund G.
Brown, Jr., et al.; and
No. 72-6050. Laurence H. Frommhagen, appellant, v. Edmund G.
Brown, Jr., et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed in part and
vacated in part and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Northern District of California for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
No. 72-887. American Party of Texas et al., appellants, v. Mark
White, Jr., Secretary of State of Texas; and
No. 72-942. Robert Hainsworth, appellant, v. Mark White, Jr.,
Secretary of State of Texas. Appeals from the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas. Judgment affirmed in part
and vacated in part and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas for further consideration in
light of Goosby v. Osser, 409 U.S. 512 (1973) and O'Brien v. Skinner,
414 U.S. — (1974). Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas dissenting in part.

TUESDAY, MARCH 26, 1974
445
No. 73-88. United States, petitioner, v. Eugene H. Edwards and
William T. Livesay. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated as to respondent
Livesay and remanded to the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Ohio with directions to dismiss the indictment.
Judgment as to respondent Edwards reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 71-6852. Donald Paul Lubin, etc., petitioner, v. Leonard
Panish, Registrar-Recorder, County of Los Angeles. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in part with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT

from appellees.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1974
446
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-985. Hensley K. Wood, appellant, v. Margaret K. Wood
Atkinson. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-1218. Emeral D. Pfeifer et al., appellants, v. The Board of
Education of the Upper Sandusky Exempted Village School District.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Wyandot County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–1188. Helene Wohlgemuth, etc., et al., appellants, v. Mar-
lene Williams, on behalf of the minor, Algeron Walker, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Pennsylvania. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-1252. National Union of Hospital and Nursing Home Em-
ployees, AFL-CIO, RWDSU, Local 1199-W. Va., et al., appellants,
v. Bluefield Sanitarium, Inc., etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-5943. Tommie Caruthers, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California. First Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 73-6022. James E. Diggs, Jr., appellant, v. George A. Ross
et al. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.

No. A-881. Emil Sapere, applicant, v. United States. The appli-
cation for stay of the execution and enforcement of the judgment of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit presented
to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied.

cation for stay of the execution and enforcement of the judgment of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, presented
to Mr. Justice Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. D-20. In Matter of Disbarment of Robert Bernard Levin.
Order of Disbarment entered.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The motion of the United States for leave to amend the complaint is
granted.
No. 72–1554. Super Tire Engineering Company et al., petitioners,
v. Lloyd W. McCorkle et al. The motion of the petitioners for leave
to file a supplemental brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 73–375. William Otte, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Freedomland,
Inc., petitioner, v. United States and the City of New York. The
motion of the respondent City of New York for divided argument is
granted.
No. 73–582. City of Pittsburgh, petitioner, v. Alco Parking Cor-
poration et al. The motion of the Council for Private Enterprise
et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
No. 73–696. The Emporium Capwell Co., petitioner, v. Western
Addition Community Organization; and
No. 73-830. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. West-
ern Addition Community Organization et al. The motion of Depart-
ment Store Employees Union for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
is granted.
No. 73–6430. Peter M. Bekeny, petitioner, v. United States. The
application for stay of the execution and enforcement of the judg-
ment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit,
presented to Mr. Justice White and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.

No. 73-5688. Dewey Hart, petitioner, v. Ira M. Coiner, Warden;
No. 73-5846. David Dulles, petitioner, v. Pamela Dulles; and
No. 73–5983. Eugene Whatley, petitioner, v. Park J. Anderson,
Warden, et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.

OPINIONS
458
No. 72-985. The California Bankers Association, appellant, v.
George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.;
No. 72-1073. George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.,
appellants, v. The California Bankers Association et al.; and
No. 72-1196. Fortney H. Stark, Jr., et al., appellants, v. George P.
Shultz et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California. Judgment affirmed in part and re-
versed in part and cases remanded to the United States District Court
for the Northern District of California for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr.
Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
No. 73–191. Village of Belle Terre et al., appellants, v. Bruce
Boraas et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Adjourned until Monday, April 15, 1974, at 10 o'clock.







☐ (Journal)
MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1974
459
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–1131. James S. Mahon, Trustee, and C.I.T. Corporation,
petitioners, v. Curtis R. Stowers et al. On petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70–120. J. W. Mailliard III et al., appellants, v. Frank
Gonzalez, through Maria Alvarez, his guardian ad litem, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
California. Motion of the appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California for
reconsideration of the injunction in light of Steffel v. Thompson, 415
U.S. (1974), and Zwickler v. Koota, 389 U.S. 241 (1967). Mr.
Justice Douglas would affirm the judgment.
-
No. 71-1511. David L. Norvell, Attorney General of the State of
New Mexico, appellant, v. A. L. Happy Apodaca. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of New Mexico. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of New Mexico for further consideration in light
of Lubin v. Panish, 415 U.S. (1974).
No. 72-193. Donald L. Fowler et al., appellants, v. John Bolt
Culbertson. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of South Carolina. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina
for further consideration in light of Lubin v. Panish, 415 U.S.—
(1974).

Appeals from the United States District Court for the Middle District

of Florida for further consideration in light of Lubin v. Panish, 415

No. 72-1734. Elizabeth Samkowski, Acting Director of the
Marion County Department of Public Welfare, etc., appellant, v.

No. 73-37. Wayne Stanton, Director, Indiana State Department

States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana for further
consideration in light of Edelman v. Jordan, 415 U.S. - (1974).
Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm judgment for the reasons set forth
in his dissent in Edelman v. Jordan, 415 U.S. — (1974). Mr. Justice
Brennan would affirm judgment.

No. 73-544. Fred Carroll Lucas and Ronnie Ray Lucas, appel-
lants. v. Arkansas. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Arkansas for further consideration in light of Lewis v. City of New
Orleans, 415 U.S. - (1974). (See dissenting opinion of Mr. Justice
Douglas in this case and in Karian v. City of Cincinnati, 73–537:
Kelly v. Ohio. 72-1379; and Rosen v. California, 72-1738.) Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom the Chief Justice
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 73-893. Communist Party et al., appellants, v. Richard Austin,
etc.. et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Michigan. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
Michigan for further consideration in light of American Party of
Texas v. White, 415 U.S. (1974).
-
No. 73-955. Raul N. Ceja, appellant, v. State Police Merit Board
of the State of Illinois et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.



MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1974
461
No. 73-1184. Schwegmann Brothers Giant Super Markets, appel-
lant, v. Louisiana Milk Commission; and
No. 73-1259. Louisiana Milk Commission, appellant, v. Schweg-
mann Brothers Giant Super Markets. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana. Judgment
affirmed.
No. 73-1292. Zanes-Ewalt Warehouse, Inc., appellant, v. Robert
S. Calvert et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Texas. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–1302. Community Consolidated School District Number
210, La Salle County, Illinois, et al., appellants, v. Joe L. Mini, County
Superintendent of Schools of La Salle County, Illinois, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–1297. Everson Evangelical Church of North America et al.,
appellants, v. Western Pennsylvania Conference of the United Meth-
odist Church. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, West-
ern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 73-5954. Mary Doe, etc., et al., appellants, v. Edwin F.
Flowers, Commissioner of the West Virginia Department of Welfare.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of West Virginia. Motion of appellants for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas
would reverse the judgment for the reasons set forth in his dissent in
Edelman v. Jordan, 415 U.S. (1974). Mr. Justice Brennan dissents
and would reverse judgment for the reasons set forth in his dissent in
Edelman v. Jordan, 415 U.S.— (1974)

Liberties Union et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is

Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.

to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, is denied.

of the Navy et al. The motion for the appointment of counsel is
granted, and it is ordered that William A. Dougherty of Tustin, Cali-
fornia, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the petitioners in this case.

Edison Company. The motion of the Public Service Commission of

OPINIONS
No. 72-1118. Alvin J. Arnett, Director, Office of Economic Oppor-
tunity, et al., appellants, v. Wayne Kennedy, etc., et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further proceedings in
conformity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Rehnquist
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in
which Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Stewart join. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and concurring in the result
in part in which Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan concur.
No. 72-1554. Super Tire Engineering Company et al., petitioners,
v. Lloyd W. McCorkle et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings on the
merits of the controversy. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17, 1974
484
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-

OPINION
No. 72-914. Sarah Scheuer, Administratrix, etc., petitioner, v.
James Rhodes et al.; and
No. 72-1318. Arthur Krause, Administrator of the Estate of
Allison Krause, et al., petitioners, v. James Rhodes et al. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before we proceed with the arguments that we interrupted at the
close of the session yesterday, I would like to make a very brief
statement.
"Today marks an event in the history of this Court that has never
occurred before, and may never occur again.
"It is also a milestone in the unique judicial career of Mr. Justice
Douglas, who, on October 29, 1973, established a record of the longest
service of any one of the one hundred Justices who have served on
this Court, in the one hundred and eighty-four years since the Court
first sat on February 2, 1790.
540-278-74-90



WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17, 1974
485
"It was precisely thirty-five years ago today that Mr. Justice
Douglas took his seat on this Court.
"A great many people exceed the Biblical three-score-and-ten and
go on to eighties and the nineties and even beyond that, but few of
them do so with the remarkable vigor and the full zest for life that
Justice Douglas exhibits. His curiosity and concern about the world
we live in and all that is in it and his search to satisfy that curiosity
seems to increase with each passing year.
"This week he publishes his seventeenth book, an account of his early
years in Minnesota, in the State of Washington, then back east to
New York, and later at New Haven, and then in Washington, where
he came to spend four or five months and has remained forty years.
"Anyone who thinks Justice Douglas is nearing the end of his
career overlooks the reality of his life and his temperament. There
are many more mountains to climb, mountains of the Law, mountains
of life and of nature, and that will always be his pursuit.
"On October 29 last year, when Justice Douglas surpassed all the
prior records of service, he made a statement that ought to be placed
in the permanent records of this Court, and I will take this occasion.
to do so.
"He said this:
'I think the heart of America is sound. I think the conscience of
America is bright. I think the future of America is great. The thing
that holds us all together is not the wording of the Constitution, but
the mucilage of good will, and that is what we need at all times."
"I know, Mr. Justice Douglas, our Brother Douglas, that I speak
for all the members of the Court as well as for our retired brethren,
Mr. Chief Justice Warren, Justices Reed and Clark, and former mem-
bers of the Court with whom you sat, when I say that we salute you
on this occasion, and wish you good health and the continued vigor
that has been your trademark for all these years."
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-754. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., appellants, v. Booker T. Hillery, Jr., et al.;
and

tions, et al. Argument continued by Mr. Stanley A. Bass for Hillery

John T. Murphy for Procunier et al.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-

The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1217. Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Com-
pany et al., appellants, v. Nueces County Navigation District et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of Texas. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Texas with direc-
tions to dismiss the case as moot.
No. 73-6346. William J. Toland, appellant, v. New Jersey. Appeal
from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-6355. Margit E. Klein, appellant, v. Henry Mayo and
Albert P. Pettoruto, Justices of Probate Court for Essex County, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed.
No.

REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 73-849. Perry Russell Tunnell, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 73-1009. Hayden Stone Incorporated, and HS Equities, Inc.,
petitioners, v. Gus T. Piantes et al.;
No. 73-1154. Gerald P. Wolf, petitioner, v. Terri L. Wolf;
No. 73-6118. Florence Keil, petitioner, v. Helen P. Reinke Glover;
and
No. 73-6186. Joseph J. Smilgus, petitioner, v. Harold D. Kimmel
et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 72–637. Kennecott Copper Corporation, petitioner, v. Federal
Trade Commission. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
AMENDMENTS TO THE FEDERAL RULES OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE
1. That the Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United States
District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein Rules 12.1, 12.2, and 29.1 and amendments to Rules 4, 9(a),
11, 12, 14, 16, 17 (f), 20, 32 (a), 32(c), 32(e), and 43.
2. That the amendments and additions to the Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1974, and shall govern all



MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1974
496
criminal proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and
practicable, in proceedings then pending.
3. That The Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit to the Congress the amendments and additions to the Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of title 18,
United States Code, sections 3771 and 3772.
Mr. Justice Douglas is opposed to the Court being a mere conduit
of Rules to Congress since the Court has had no hand in drafting
them and has no competence to design them in keeping with the titles
and spirit of the Constitution.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 29, 1974, until
Monday, May 13, 1974.

proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Option by

per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.

(Journal)
THURSDAY, APRIL 25, 1974
503
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-986. John L. Hill, Attorney General of Texas, applicant, v.
Michael L. Stone, et al. The application for partial stay presented
to Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is granted
and it is ordered that the judgment of the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Texas be stayed to the extent
that it prohibits the use of the dual-box election procedure. This stay
order is to remain in effect pending the timely filing and disposition
of an appeal in this Court. If the appeal is timely filed, this stay shall
remain in effect pending the issuance of the judgment of this Court.
The Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
Mr. Justice Douglas said:
"The Chief Justice is unavoidably absent this morning, but hopes
to be able to participate in the decision of the case on the basis of
the recorded argument and the briefs.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-690. Air Pollution Variance Board of the State of Colorado.
petitioner, v. Western Alfalfa Corporation. One and one half hours
allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. William Tucker for the
petitioner, by Mr. Edmund W. Ketch for the United States, as amicus
curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Donald D. Cawelti for
the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, April 29, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
(Journal)
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
504
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1077. Berry Transport, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Oregon. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-1126. Raymond H. Wilson et ux., appellants, v. Depart-
ment of Revenue, State of Oregon. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-6391. Richard R. Scheffel and Hideo Saiki, appellants, v.
Washington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-6404. Bailey M. Smith, appellant, v. Hugh John Askins.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division 2. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–6054. Dwayne Anthony Cole and Ray Durham, appellants,
v. California. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 73-6313. Simeon Simpkins, etc., appellant, v. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Claims. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 73-6099. Charlie W. Ward et al., appellants, v. Richard M.
Nixon, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 73-6459. Thelma Washington et al., appellants, v. Mark
White, Jr., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
540-278-74--96



MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
505
for the Northern District of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want
of an appealable order.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-5694. Manuel Andrade-Gamiz, petitioner, v. Immigra-
tion and Naturalization Service. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with directions to dismiss cause as moot.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-928. Bonnie L. Ohmert, applicant, v. Jeanette Young et al.
The application for stay presented to Mr. Justice Stewart, and by
him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1026. Melvin M. Belli, applicant, v. State Bar of Cali-
fornia. The application for stay of judgment of the Supreme Court of
California presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied. The Chief Justice took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this application.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky. The second motion of the State of Ohio for reconsidera-
tion of the order of March 5, 1973, is denied.
No. 36, Original. State of Texas, plaintiff, v. State of Louisiana.
The motion of the City of Port Arthur, Texas, for leave to intervene
is granted. The motion of the City of Port Arthur, Texas, for a more
definite statement is denied.
No. 73–187. Kewanee Oil Company, petitioner, v. Bicron Corpo-
ration et al. The motion of SCM Corporation for leave to file a sup-
plemental brief, as amicus curiae, after argument, is denied.
No. 73–296. Lawrence S. Huffman, etc., et al., appellants, v.
Pursue, Ltd. The motion of appellants for leave to utilize portions of
record printed for use as an appendix to jurisdictional statement in
preparing single appendix as required by Rule 17 is denied.
No. 73–362. Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, et al.,
appellants, v. C. R. Mancari et al. The motion of the National Federa-
tion of Federal Employees for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is
denied.
No. 73–679. Charles Wolff, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Robert
O. McDonnell, etc. The motion of the Ohio State University College of
Law Clinical Programs for leave to file an untimely brief, as amicus
curiae, is denied.



MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
506
No. 73-1148. Cheryl Spider DeCoteau, natural mother and next
friend of Robert Lee Feather and Herbert John Spider, etc., peti-
tioner, v. The District County Court for the Tenth Judicial District.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing
the views of the United States on or before May 14, 1974.
No. 73–5845. Catherine Jackson, etc., petitioner, v. Metropolitan
Edison Company. The motion of the Legal Aid Foundation of Long
Beach et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 73-1406. Daniel Chapman and Jacque Stockman, appellants,
v. Ben Meier, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of North Dakota. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 73-1055. Bowman Transportation, Inc., appellant,
Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
v.
No. 73–1069. Johnson Motor Lines, Inc., appellant, v. Arkansas-
Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
No. 73-1070. Red Ball Motor Freight, Inc., appellant, v.
Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al.;
No. 73–1071. Lorch-Westway Corporation et al., appellants, v.
Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al.; and
No. 73-1072. United States and Interstate Commerce Commission,
appellants, v. Arkansas-Best Freight System, Inc., et al. Appeals
from the United States District Court for the Western District of
Arkansas. In case No. 73-1055 probable jurisdiction noted limited to
questions 2 and 4 presented by the jurisdictional statement which read
as follows:
"2. Can a Three-Judge District Court lawfully set aside and en-
join an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission granting an
extension of a motor carrier certificate on the ground the Court does
not agree with the order or may consider the evidence would warrant
a different conclusion?
"4. Whether Commission order issued following extensive hearings,
involving a voluminous record, admittedly concluding within all time
limitations and commission rules can be judicially determined to be
so stale 'as a matter of law' to prohibit any required finding or further
consideration. If so, when does such an administrative action reach
that point?"
In case No. 73-1069 probable jurisdiction noted limited to question
2 presented by the jurisdictional statement which reads as follows:
"2. Whether in reversing the Commission's decision awarding certi-
ficates of public convenience and necessity the District Court employed



MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
507
erroneous standards of judicial review and improperly substituted its
judgment for that of the agency."
In case No. 73-1070 probable jurisdiction noted limited to (3) and
(5) of the question presented by the jurisdictional statement which
reads as follows:
"Whether the three-judge court, in setting aside the administrative
agency decision, abdicated or abandoned its judicial function by
(3) failing to give independent judicial consideration and review
to the separate grants of authority to the intervening defendant motor
carriers;
(5) rejecting Supreme Court precedent limiting the Court's scope
of review and thereby substituting its judgment for that of the agency
charged with the responsibility therefor;"
In case No. 73-1071 probable jurisdiction noted limited to question
2 presented by the jurisdictional statement which reads as follows:
"Whether the Three-Judge District Court improperly adopted a novel
and unwarranted concept of de novo review of Commission decisions
and changed the statutory relationship between hearing examiners
and their agency with respect to recommended and final decisions."
In case No. 73-1072 probable jurisdiction is noted. Cases consoli-
dated and a total of one and one-half hours allotted for oral argument.
No. 73–1210. Interstate Commerce Commission, appellant, v.
Oregon Pacific Industries, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Oregon. Motion of Western Rail-
road Traffic Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.

No. 73–1290. United States, petitioner, v. ITT Continental
Baking Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.

Upper South Department, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. Quality Manu-
facturing Company, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted and the case
is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 73-1363.
No. 73-1363. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v.
J. Weingarten, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted and the case is set
for oral argument in tandem with No. 73–765.
No. 73-1377. Russell E. Train, Administrator, United States
Environmental Protection Agency, petitioner, v. City of New York
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted; and

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments.
in the cases listed for hearing today.

MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1974
OPINIONS
522
No. 72-6902. Lonnie Gooding, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall concur. Dissenting opinión
by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan join.
No. 72-1465. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California De-
partment of Corrections, et al., appellants, v. Robert Martinez et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of California. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 73-439. Lehman Brothers, petitioner, v. Jacob Schein et al.;
No. 73-440. Benjamin Simon, petitioner, v. Jacob Schein and
Marvin H. Schein; and
No. 73-495. Investors Diversified Services, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Jacob Schein et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals so that it may reconsider
whether the controlling issue of Florida law should be certified to the
Flordia Supreme Court pursuant to Rule 4.61 of the Florida Appellate
Rules. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 73-831. Warden, Lewisburg Penitentiary, petitioner, v.
Benigno Marrero. Argued by Mrs. Jewel S. Lafontant for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. John J. Witmeyer, III, for the respondent, pro hac
vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 73-781. Fritz Scherk, petitioner, v. Alberto-Culver Company.
Argued by Mr. Robert F. Hanley for the petitioner, by Mr. Gerald
Aksen for the American Arbitration Association, as amicus curiae,
by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Francis J. Higgins for the
respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, May 13, 1974, at 10 o'clock.







(Journal)
MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
523
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1173. International Business Machines Corporation, ap-
pellant, v. United States. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Douglas would postpone jurisdic-
tion to a hearing of the case on the merits. Mr. Justice Blackmun and
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 72-1617. Civil Service Commission of the State of New York
et al., appellants, v. Marie Snead; and
No. 72-1691. Department of Social Services of the City of New
York et al., appellants, v. Marie Snead. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Judg-
ment vacated and cases remanded to the United States District Court
for the Southern District of New York for further consideration in
light of Arnett v. Kennedy, 416 U.S. — (1974).
No. 73–90. Walter S. Shelton, appellant, v. Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission et al. Appeal from the United States District.
Court for the Western District of Washington. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-865. Morgan Drive Away, Inc., appellant, v. United States
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Oklahoma. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-1273. Florida Texas Freight, Inc., appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–208. Richard Collins et al., appellants, v. Malcolm Wilson,
* Governor of State of New York. et al. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of New York. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals of New York for further consideration in light of Arnett v.
Kennedy, 416 U.S.—— (1974).
540-278-74-
-99



MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
524
No. 73–219. Thomas J. Sanford et al., appellants, v. Malcolm
Wilson et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Judg-
ments vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York
for further consideration in light of Arnett v. Kennedy, 416 U.S.—
(1974).
No. 73–1066. Cravath, Swaine & Moore, appellant, v. United
States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Motion to treat jurisdictional
statement as motion for leave to file petition for writ mandamus and/or
certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case and motion.
No. 73-1130. Thomas M. Lilly, appellant, v. Katherine T. Lilly.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–1419. Frank F. Stuart, appellant, v. Dorothea A. Stuart.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-6182. Alfonso Terry Johnson, appellant, v. Maryland. Ap-
peal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set
case for oral argument.
No. 73–6207. Duane Pope, appellant, v. Nebraska. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas
would dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction, treat papers sub-
mitted as petition for writ of certiorari and set case for oral argument
on the issue of double jeopardy in light of his dissent in Bartkus v.
Illinois, 359 U.S. 121, 150, 164. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-925. In the Matter of M. A. C., applicant. The application
for release pending trial in the Superior Court of the District of
Columbia presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to
the Court, is denied.
No. A-987. Walter Walden, applicant, v. John L. McLucas, Under
Secretary of the Air Force, et al. The reapplication for an injunction
pending appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth

1

MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
525
Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. A-1058. Thomas Buck et al., applicants, v. Impeach Nixon
Committee et al. The application for stay of the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit presented to
the Chief Justice, and by him referred to the Court is granted. The
motion to vacate the stay heretofore granted by the Chief Justice
is denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, and Mr. Justice Powell would discontinue the stay.
No. A-1065. Local 391, International Brotherhood of Teamsters,
etc., applicant, v. Pilot Freight Carriers, Inc. The application for
a s'ay of the mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit presented to the Chief Justice, and by him referred
to the Court, is denied.
No. D-11. In the Matter of Disbarment of Benjamin Gerard
Hartzog. Order of disbarment entered.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to file a supplemental brief,
after argument, is granted.
No. 73–671. Mayer Paving and Asphalt Company et al., petition-
ers, v. General Dynamics Corporation et al. The respondents are re-
quested to file a response to the motion for leave to file petition for
rehearing within thirty days.
No. 73–831. Warden, Lewisburg Penitentiary, petitioner, v.
Benigno Marrero. The motion of the respondent for appointment of
counsel, nunc pro tunc, is granted. It is ordered that John J. Witmeyer
III of New York, New York, be, and he is hereby, appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 73-5845. Catherine Jackson, etc., petitioner, v. Metropolitan
Edison Company. The motion of the National Consumer Law Center
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 73-1046. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of the Depart-
ment of Health, Education, and Welfare, appellant, v. Santiago Diaz
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Florida. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1256. Connell Construction Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
Plumbers and Steamfitters Local Union No. 100, etc. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit granted.



MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
526
No. 73-1313. International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation,
Communications Equipment and Systems Division, petitioner, v.
Local 134, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL-
CIO. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 73–1162. United States, petitioner, v. Thomas Joseph Wilson
and Bobby Antonio Bryan. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 73–1288. Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., petitioner, v. The
Republic of Cuba et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted. Counsel are
directed to brief and argue the following questions:
"1. Can statements by counsel for the Republic of Cuba, that peti-
tioner's unjust enrichment counterclaim would not be honored, con-
stitute an act of state?
"2. If so, is an exception to the act of state doctrine created, under
First National City Bank v. Banco Nacional de Cuba, 406 U.S. 759
(1972), where petitioner's counterclaim does not exceed the net balance
owed to Cuba on its claims by petitioner's co-defendants, and where
all claims and counterclaims arise out of the subject matter in litiga-
tion in this case?"
No. 73-6038. James Edward Drope, petitioner, v. Missouri. Mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, St. Louis District,
granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 73-221. Ruth Robinson, petitioner, v. Board of Regents of
Eastern Kentucky University et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.

No. 73–1303. Jerome B. Rosenthal et ux., petitioners, v. Commis-

No. 73-1325. Salvatore Montello et al., petitioners, v. United

MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
OPINIONS
547
No. 72–1570. Robert H. Donnelly, petitioner, v. Benjamin A. De-
Christoforo. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice White joins.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall would affirm judgment below for the reasons
stated in Part II of the dissent of Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72-1057. United States, petitioner, v. Dominic Nicholas
Giordano et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas in this case, and con-
curring in part and dissenting in part in No. 72-1319 post, with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 72-1319. United States, petitioner, v. Umberto Jose Chavez
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in part and dis-
senting in part in this case, and joining in No. 72-1057, ante, with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall concur.
No. 72-6160. Lawrence Mitchell, petitioner, 2. W. T. Grant Com-
pany. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall concur. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan is in agreement that Fuentes v. Shevin, 407 U.S. 67
(1972). requires reversal of judgment of Supreme Court of Louisiana.
No. 73-641. Edwin A. Snow, et ux., petitioners. ". Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr.
Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.



MONDAY, MAY 13, 1974
548
No. 73-187. Kewanee Oil Company, petitioner, v. Bicron Corpora-
tion et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals with directions to reinstate the judgment of the
District Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan concurs. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
Adjourned until Wednesday, May 15, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

540-278-74-102

(Journal)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 15, 1974
549
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Powell.
OPINIONS
No. 72-1470. Bob Jones University, petitioner, v. William E.
Simon, Secretary of Treasury, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun con-
curring in the result. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision
of this case.
No. 72-1371. Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Rev-
enue, petitioner, v. "Americans United" Inc. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 73-5412. John R. Dillard and Willie Williams, etc., appellants,
v. Industrial Commission of Virginia et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Virginia for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 72–1322. Carolyn Bradley et al., petitioners, v. School Board
of City of Richmond et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 72–1597. Ulysses Vernon Beasley et al., petitioners, v. Food
Fair of North Carolina, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan.
540-278-74- -103



WEDNESDAY, MAY 15, 1974
550
No. 73-157. Astol Calero-Toledo, Superintendent of Police, et al.,
appellants, v. Pearson Yacht Leasing Co. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Puerto Rico for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Statement
by Mr. Justice Stewart joining in Parts I and II. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Adjourned until Monday, May 20, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
