OPINIONS
563
No. 72-1660. Stanley Blackledge, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Jimmy Seth Perry. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins in Part II.
No. 73–5280. Prince Eric Fuller, petitioner, v. Oregon. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas
concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 73-629. Robert J. Kosydar, Tax Commissioner of Ohio, peti-
tioner, v. National Cash Register Co. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.



MONDAY, MAY 20, 1974
564
No. 73–370. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Food
Store Employees Union, Local 347, etc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with
directions to remand to the Board for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan.
No. 73–466. William E. Arnold Company, petitioner, v. Carpenters
District Council of Jacksonville and Vicinity, etc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan.
No. 72–1125. A. Y. Allee et al., appellants, v. Francisco Medrano
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Texas. Judgment affirmed in part and vacated in part and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Texas for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the result in part
and dissenting in part, with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
decision of this case.
No. 73–690. Air Pollution Variance Board of the State of Colorado,
petitioner, v. Western Alfalfa Corporation. On writ of certiorari to
the Court of Appeals of Colorado. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals of Colorado for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 28, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
Х



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
565
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72–1369. Elviera Walker Carmack et al., appellants, v. Errol
E. Buckner. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Motion
of Federal National Mortgage Association for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 73–777. Otter Tail Power Company, appellant, v. United
States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 73-960. John P. Marshall, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth Supreme Judicial
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-1517. Baltimore County, Maryland, et al., appellants, v.
Churchill, Ltd., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Mary-
land. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion.
No. 73-6518. Ronald W. Crandall, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73–6519. Larry Edward Winkfield, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-1305. New Hampshire Department of Employment Secu-
rity et al., appellant, v. Francis H. Pregent. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of New Hampshire. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
* the District of New Hampshire to consider the question of mootness.
540-278-74-106



TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
566
No. 73-1349. Florida East Coast Railway Company et al., appel-
lants, v. United States et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Middle District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 73–1391. Spielman-Fond, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Hanson's
Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Arizona. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73-6446. John W. August, appellant, v. Harry Bronstein et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–1483. Warren Simmons et al., appellants, v. Slade Gorton
et al.; and
No. 73–1484. William J. Fritz et al., appellants, v. Slade Gorton,
Attorney General of the State of Washington, et al. Appeals from the
Supreme Court of Washington. Motion of Association of Washington
Business, Inc., for substitution of representative of class party or in
the alternative for leave to intervene in No. 73–1484 denied. The
appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question,
No. 73–1491. Hartley Haines, appellant, v. Reubin O'D. Askew
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73-6220. James E. Diggs, Jr., appellant, v. William P. Berzak,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 73-6483. Herbert Nival, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 71-1410. Vincent Peter Pisacano et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of United States v. Giordano, 416
U.S. (1974).
No. 72-158. Richard Becker and Jack Eisen, petitioners, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari



TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
567
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of United States v. Giordano, 416
U.S.
(1974).
No. 72-1729. Emmanuel Simons, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 72-6992. Anthony Favano, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 73-13. Francis G. Romanello et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion of petitioner in No. 72-
6992 for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petitions for writs
of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of United States
v. Giordano, 416 U.S. — (1974).
-
No. 73–856. Elvin Lee Bynum et al., petitioners, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of United States v. Giordano, 416 U.S.
(1974). Mr. Justice Douglas would reverse judgment. United States
v. Giordano, 416 U.S. (1974) and United States v. Chavez, 416
-
U.S. — (1974) (Douglas J., dissenting).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 32 Original. State of Missouri, plaintiff, v. State of Nebraska.
The motion to dismiss per stipulation is denied without prejudice
to the parties' filing of a proper motion under Rule 60 of the Rules of
this Court. Kansas v. Colorado, 382 U.S. 801 (1965); see State of
Washington v. Northern Securities Co., et al., 201 U.S. 651 (1906).
No. A-1044. Robert Hoffman et ux., applicants, v. United States
Department of Housing and Urban Development et al. The applica-
tion for stay and continuation of injunction presented to Mr. Justice
Stewart, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1058. Thomas Buck, Director, Communications and Mar-
keting, et al., applicants, v. Impeach Nixon Committee et al. The appli-
cations of the respondents to shorten the time in which to file petition
for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-1081. Marriott Corporation et al., applicants, v. D. C. Min-
imum Wage and Industrial Safety Board. The application for stay of
enforcement of the Wage Order of the District of Columbia Mini-
mum Wage and Industrial Safety Board presented to the Chief
Justice, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. The order of
the Chief Justice heretofore entered May 13, 1974, is hereby vacated.
No. A-1093. Ellen P. McDonald, etc., et al., applicants, v. John
McLucas, Acting Secretary of Air Force, et al. The application for



TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
568
stay of judgment of the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York, and for other relief, presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. The motion of the respondents for leave to file a supplemental
brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 73-477. Richard E. Gerstein, State Attorney for Eleventh
Judicial Circuit of Florida, petitioner, v. Robert Pugh et al.; and
No. 73–1575. John D. Callahan et al., petitioners, v. Charles E.
Kimball et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file briefs in these
cases expressing the views of the United States.
No. 73-631. Howard Johnson Company, Inc., petitioner v. Detroit
Local Joint Executive Board, Hotel and Restaurant Employees and
Bartenders International Union, AFL-CIO. The motion of the peti-
tioner for leave to file a supplemental brief, after argument, is granted.
No. 73-1681. George Steinbert and Son, Inc., petitioner, v. Earl L.
Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, et al. The application for stay of the
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the
Court, is denied.
No. 73-5772. Anthony Pasquall Faretta, petitioner, v. California.
The motion of the petitioner for appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Jerome B. Balk, Jr., of San Francisco, Cali-
fornia, a member of the Bar of this Court be, and he is hereby, ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 73-1462. Mark White et al., appellants, v. Diana Regester et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western Dis-
trict of Texas. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice
Douglas would affirm judgment.

petition which reads as follows:



TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
569
"2. Whether petitioners' convictions of conspiracy represent a du-
plication of their convictions of violating 18 U.S.C. 1955 and require
that the conspiracy convictions be reversed."

and case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 73–1316. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

of this petition.

for the Third Circuit granted and case set for oral argument in tandem
with No. 73–1513.
No. 73-1513. United States, petitioner, v. Ronald S. Jenkins.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.

for the Second Circuit granted and case set for oral argument in tan-
dem with No. 73–1395.
No. 73-1471. United States et al., petitioners, v. New Jersey State
Lottery Commission. Motion of National Association of Broadcasters
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
granted.

No. 73–1257. Lindbergh Kirby, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
No. 73-1311. Michael Papadopoulos, petitioner, v. Oregon State
Board of Higher Education. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court
of Appeals of Oregon denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant
certiorari.

579

TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
580
No. 73-1003. National Indian Youth Council et al., petitioners, v.

ents denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would
grant certiorari.

istrator, Environmental Protection Agency. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-

tioner, v. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, et al. Petition

in the consideration or decision of this petition.

States for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 73-1180, granted.

for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.

petitioner, v. Willie Glinsey and Euan Bailey. Motion of respondents

denied.

writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Di-
vision, denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 73-6579. William Mayer, petitioner, v. Julius Moeykens. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Black-
mun, upon the suggestion of the petitioner's death prior to the filing
the petition for certiorari, would dismiss the petition.

L. Means. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of certiorari denied.

MOTION
589
No. 73-1745. Britt Hume, petitioner, v. Edward L. Carey. The
application for a stay of the judgment of the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit presented to the Chief
Justice, and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant
the stay.
OPINIONS
No. 73–203. Morton Eisen, etc., petitioner, v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall concur.
No. 73-9. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v. Na-
tional Alfalfa Dehydrating and Milling Company. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Stewart concurs in
the judgment and in Parts I, II, and III of the opinion.
No. 73–190. Isadore H. Bellis, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-726. Cooper Stevedoring Company, Inc., petitioner, v.
Fritz Kopke, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the deci-
sion of this case.
No. 72-1382. F. D. Rich Co., Inc., and Transamerica Insurance Co.,
petitioners, v. United States for the Use of Industrial Lumber Com-
pany, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals



TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1974
590
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73–604. Donald C. Cass, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 73-5661. Francis A. Adams et al., petitioners, v. Secretary of
the Navy et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-841. Cale J. Holder, United States District Judge for the
Southern District of Indiana, petitioner, v. Arthur Banks. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Per
Curiam opinion announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 3, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
☑



(JOUNRAL)
FRIDAY, MAY 31, 1974
591
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice.
Rehnquist.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73–1766. United States, petitioner, v. Richard M. Nixon, Pres-
ident of the United States, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
and motion for an expedited schedule granted. The parties shall ex-
change and file briefs by 1:00 p.m. on June 21 and any responsive
brief shall be filed by July 1, 1974. Oral argument is set for July 8,
1974, at 10:00 a.m. Each party is allowed one hour for argument.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision.
of this motion and petition.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1974
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
592
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 50, Original. State of Vermont, plaintiff, v. State of New York
et al. On Bill of Complaint. Proposed settlement and consent decree
disapproved. Opinion per curiam.
No. 73-1157. Richard E. Gerstein et al., appellants, v. Nancy Coe
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari before judgment, certiorari is denied. Opinion per curiam.
No. 73-1283. Paula Poe et al., appellants, v. Richard E. Gerstein
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–1568. Orrell's Mutual Burial Association, Inc., appellant,
1. Mrs. Robert Adair, Representative of Maggie Bange. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-6272. Arthur M. Almeida, appellant, v. Massachusetts.
Appeal from the District Court of Western Norfolk, Massachu-
setts. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. (28 U.S.C.
1257).
No. 73-6366. Karl J. Bray, appellant, v. United States et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Utah.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 73–6565. Ervin A. Haas, appellant, v. Albert P. Haas et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable juris-
diction and set case for oral argument.
540-278-74— -111



MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1974
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
593
No. 73-1475. Harris County Commissioners Court et al., appel-
lants, v. Richard E. Moore et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Texas. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1347. The Board of School Commissioners of the City of
Indianapolis et al., petitioners, v. Jeff Jacobs et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit granted.
No. 73-1148. Cheryl Spider DeCoteau, Natural Mother and Next
Friend of Robert Lee Feather and Herbert John Spider, etc., peti-
tioner, v. The District County Court for the Tenth Judicial District.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota
granted and case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 73-1500.
No. 73-1500. Don R. Erickson, Warden, petitioner, v. John Lee
Feather et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted and case set for
oral argument in tandem with No. 73-1148.
No. 73–1543. Willie Johnson, Jr., petitioner, v. Railway Express
Agency, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to Question 1
presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Whether the timely filing of a charge of employment dis-
crimination with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commis-
sion pursuant to Section 706 of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act
of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-5, tolls the running of the period of
limitation applicable to an action based on the same facts brought
under the Civil Rights Act of 1866, 42 U.S.C. § 1981?”
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
expressing the views of the United States.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 72-1245. St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, peti-
tioner, v. United States, Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Claims denied.
No. 73-73. AMF Incorporated, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims denied.

No. 73–988. Gary Gilbert Carlson, petitioner, v. California. Mo-
tion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit during the week of November
11, 1974, and for such additional time as may be required to prepare
for the holding of such court or to complete unfinished business, pur-
suant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this
☐ Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 10,
1974.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1154. David Kent Campbell, Lance Corporal, et al., appli-
cant, v. Michael J. Beaughler, Captain, U.S. Marine Corps Reserve,
etc., et al. The application for stay of judgment of dismissal by the
United States District Court for the District of Arizona pending ap-
peal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and by him referred to the Court,
is denied.
OPINIONS
No. 73–29. Corning Glass Works, petitioner, v. Peter J. Brennan,
Secretary of Labor, United States Department of Labor. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit; and
No. 73-695. Peter J. Brennan, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
Corning Glass Works. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment in No. 73-29 affirmed.
Judgment in No. 73-695 reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent and would
affirm judgment in No. 73–695 and reverse judgment in No. 73–29 for
the reasons stated by Judge Adams in his opinion for the Court of



MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1974
606
Appeals in Brennan v. Corning Glass Works, 480 F. 2d 1254 (CA3).
Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 73–346. William N. Anderson et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Mar-
shall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan concurs.
No. 73-631. Howard Johnson Company, Inc., petitioner, v. Detroit
Local Joint Executive Board, Hotel and Restaurant Employees and
Bartenders International Union AFL-CIO. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
Adjourned until Monday, June 10, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
Х







(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1974
607
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackman, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-1322. David Kent Alonso et al., appellants, v. Georgia.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-1437. Indiana Real Estate Commission et al., appellants,
v. Vijay V. Satoskar. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Indiana. Judgment affirmed. In re Grif-
fiths, 413 U.S. 717 (1973). Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents.
No. 73–1554. Wayne Ramsay, appellant, v. Santa Rosa Medical
Center et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas,
Fourth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73-1585. Margaret Batterham Waters, appellant, v. Fred
Henderson et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Tennessee,
Western Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 73–6271. John Michaels, anonymous juvenile, etc., appellant,
v. Arizona. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 73-1396. Arthur Marcus, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Upon the representation of the Solicitor General set forth in his
memorandum for the United States filed May 31, 1974, judgment
540-278-74- -113



MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1974
608
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
Government.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. In the Matter of Resignation of Stuart F. Dye. The
request of Stuart F. Dye, of Knoxville, Tennessee, that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice in this
Court is granted.
No. A-1053. John Paul Anderson, applicant, v. South Carolina.
The application for bail pending appeal, presented to Mr. Justice
Douglas and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1140. Jeffrey Hart et al., applicants, v. Community School
Board of Brooklyn et al. The application to vacate the order of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and
to reinstate the judgment of the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of New York, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. A-1157. Donald M. Severson et al., applicants, v. Arthur C.
Roemer et al. The application for stay of implementation of the
Minnesota Tax Credit-Payment Act, M.S.A. §§ 290.086 and 290.087,
presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant the stay.
No. 73-1742. Russell E. Train, Administrator, United States
Environmental Protection Agency, et al., petitioners, v. Natural Re-
sources Defense Council, Inc., et al. The application for stay of Part
III of the order of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the
Court, is granted pending final disposition of the petition for writ of
certiorari. Mr. Justice Douglas dissents from granting the stay.
No. 73-1748. Clifford Lavern Bishop et al., petitioners, v. United
States. The application for stay of the mandate of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit and for release pending dis-
position of the petition for writ of certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice
Marshall and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 73-6033. Sharon Roe et al., appellants, v. Nicholas Norton,
etc. The motion of the children of appellants for leave to proceed
further herein in forma pauperis is granted.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 73-1573. Harold Withrow et al., etc., appellants, v. Duane
Larkin. Appeal from the United States District Court for the



MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1974
609
Eastern District of Wisconsin. In this case probable jurisdiction
noted.
No. 73–1016. John Lascaris, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al.; and
No. 73–1095. Abe Lavine, etc., appellant, v. Sylvia Shirley, etc.,
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of New York. Motion of appellee Stuck for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. In these cases probable jurisdiction noted.
Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 73–1413. Elmer R. Staats, Comptroller-General of the United
States, et al., appellants, v. American Civil Liberties Union, Inc., et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Motion of the National Association of Broadcasters for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.

Warden. Petitions for rehearing denied.
ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June
17, 1974.

OPINIONS
No. 73–482. Michigan, petitioner, v. Thomas W. Tucker. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice White
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Douglas.
No. 73-62. Hubert Wheeler, et al., petitioners, v. Anna Barrera
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice White concurring in the judgment. Mr. Justice Marshall concurs
in the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73–582. City of Pittsburgh, petitioner, v. Alco Parking Corpo-
ration. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District, for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 72–1490. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Texaco
Inc., et al.; and



MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1974
622
No. 72–1491. Dudley T. Dougherty et al. Co-Executors, Estate of
Mrs. James R. Dougherty, et al., petitioners. v. Texaco, Inc., et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice
Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 72-1454. Joseph Anthony Davis, petitioner, v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring and dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist.
No. 73-437. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Federal Power
Commission;
No. 73-457. Public Service Commission of the State of New York,
petitioner, v. Federal Power Commission; and
No. 73-464. Municipal Distributors Group, petitioner, v. Federal
Power Commission. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
Adjourned until Monday, June 17, 1974, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, JUNE 15, 1974
623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-1834. Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States,
petitioner, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted and case consolidated with No. 73-1766. The parties shall
exchange and file briefs by 1:00 P.M. on June 21, 1974, and any re-
sponsive briefs shall be filed by July 1, 1974. Oral argument is set for
July 8, 1974, at 10:00 A.M. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. 73-1766. United States, petitioner, v. Richard M. Nixon,
President of the United States, et al.; and
No. 73-1834. Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States,
petitioner, v. United States.
1. The joint motion of the Special Prosecutor and Counsel for The
President to unseal those portions of the record ordered sealed by
the District Court on May 13, 1974, is denied, except for the following
extract from the sealed record:
"On February 25, 1974, in the course of its consideration of the
indictment in the instant case, the June 5, 1974, Grand Jury, by a vote
of 19-0, determined that there is probable cause to believe that Richard
M. Nixon (among others) was a member of the conspiracy to defraud
the United States and to obstruct justice charged in Count I of the
instant indictment, and the Grand Jury authorized the Special Pros-
ecutor to identify Richard M. Nixon (among others) as an unindicted
co-conspirator in connection with subsequent legal proceedings in this
case.
"
Other than this disclosure, the sealed record shall remain sealed.
2. In addition to the questions designated by the parties in the peti-
tion for certiorari, the cross-petition for certiorari, and the petition
for a writ of mandamus filed in the Court of Appeals (Court of Ap-
peals Docket No. 74–1532), the parties are requested to brief and argue
the following questions:
(a) Is the District Court order of May 20, 1974, an appealable
order?
540-278-74– -115



SATURDAY, JUNE 15, 1974
624
(b) Does this Court have jurisdiction to entertain and decide the
petition for mandamus transmitted by the Court of Appeals to this
Court?
3. Printing of any portions of the record that have been filed in this
Court under seal shall be dispensed with. Any portions of the briefs
that counsel deem necessary to keep confidential in order to conform
with the provisions of paragraph 1 above shall be submitted under
seal to this Court, and counsel in oral argument shall refrain from
disclosing any portions of the record that are under seal.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision
of this order.



MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
625
(Journal)
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 73–899. Joseph P. Moody et al., appellants, v. Albemarle
Paper Company et al. On certificate from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Question certified to the Court an-
swered in the negative. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-120. Carl L. Marburger, State Commissioner of Education
of the State of New Jersey, et al., appellants, v. Public Funds for
Public Schools of New Jersey et al.; and
No. 73-121. Edward Griggs et al., appellants, v. Public Funds for
Public Schools of New Jersey et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the District of New Jersey. Motion of EDL-New
Jersey, Inc., for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, in No. 73–120
granted. Judgment affirmed. The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction and set
cases for oral argument.
No. 73-1321. Steve Ohley, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from the
Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 73–1440. McBryde Sugar Company, Limited, et al., appel-
lants, v. Hawaii et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
540-278-74-116



MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
626
No. 73-1570. Loren Ray Dowell et ux., appellants, v. Utah.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 73-1386. Chicago Welfare Rights Organization et al., appel-
lants, v. Joel Edelman et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illi-
nois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 73-1436. Joseph C. Daniel, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Hugh
Waters, Chairman, Textbook Commission of the State of Tennessee,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Tennessee. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee so
that it may enter a fresh judgment from which a timely appeal may
be taken to the Court of Appeals.
No. 73–1606. Murphy Nursing Home, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Rate Setting Commission et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial
Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 73-1623. Dominick Malito et al., appellants, v. John C.
Marcin et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 73-6621. Delores Schoos, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-1609. Max Rubenstein et al., appellant, v. Township of
Cherry Hill et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 73-6353. Cornelia Webster, a minor, etc., et al., appellants,
v. Alan R. Perry, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Western District of North Carolina. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Western
District of North Carolina so that it may enter a fresh judgment from
which a timely appeal may be taken to the Court of Appeals.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1175. Russell E. Train, Administrator, United States
Environmental Protection Agency, applicant, v. Texas et al. The
application for a stay of the orders of the United States District
Court for the Western District of Texas pending appeal in the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Mr. Justice
Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is granted.
No. A–1179. Thelma Cown etc., et al., applicants, v. John Vander-
hoof, Governor of Colorado. The application for a writ of habeas
corpus or in the alternative to transfer the cause to the appropriate
United States District Court for a hearing (28 U.S.C. 2241 (b)) pre-
sented to Mr. Justice White, and by him referred to the Court, is
denied.
No. D-23. In the Matter of Disbarment of Clifford Taylor Lee.
It having been reported to the Court that Clifford Taylor Lee, of
Washington, District of Columbia, has been disbarred from the prac-

1
1

MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
628
tice of law by the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit, and this Court by order of March 18, 1974, hav-
ing suspended the said Clifford Taylor Lee from the practice of law
in this Court and directed that a rule issue requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred;
And it appearing that the said rule was duly issued and served
the respondent, and that the time within which to file return
has expired;
upon
It is ordered that the said Clifford Taylor Lee be, and he is hereby,
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court and that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court.
No. 73-1626. Edward T. Weaver et al., appellants, v. Corine
Randle et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing
the views of the United States.
No. 73-1838. Giles Crisler et al., petitioners, v. Willie Morrow
et al. The application for recall and stay of the mandate of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Mr. Justice
Powell, and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED

ington. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. In this case

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 73-820. United States, petitioner, v. Pascual Guana-Sanchez.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 73–1627. Louis J. Lefkowitz, Attorney General of New York,
petitioner v. Leon Newsome. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted limited to
question 1 presented by the petition which reads as follows:
"1. Does a state defendant's plea of guilty waive federal habeas
corpus review of his conviction, even though under state law, he has

1

MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
629
been permitted review in the state appellate courts of the denial of his
motion, on constitutional grounds, to suppress the evidence that
would have been offered against him had there been a trial?"
No. 73-5993. John E. Test, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit granted limited to question 1 presented by the petition which reads
as follows:
"1. Does the Jury Selection and Service Act of 1968, 28 U.S.C.
§ 1861 et seq., require that a defendant be provided access to jury lists
and other jury records upon the filing of a sworn statement in compli-
ance with 28 U.S.C. § 1867 (d) in support of a motion to quash the
jury and upon the presentation of a prima facie claim of constitutional
dimension, i.e., the systematic exclusion of Mexican-Americans from
the jury array?"
CERTIORARI DENIED

MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
OPINIONS
641
No. 73–786. Fred R. Ross and North Carolina, petitioners, v.
Claude Franklin Moffitt. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
No. 73–362. Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, et al.,
appellants, v. C. R. Mancari, et al.; and
No. 73–364. Amerind, appellant, v. C. R. Mancari et al. Appeals
from the United States District Court for the District of New Mexico.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of New Mexico for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
No. 72-1517. Georgia Theresa Gilmore et al., petitioners, v. City
of Montgomery, Alabama, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed
in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions
to remand to the United States District Court for the Middle District
of Alabama for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White concurring in the judgment, with whom Mr. Justice
Douglas joins.
No. 72-1603. Harold J. Cardwell, Warden, petitioner, v. Arthur
Ben Lewis. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Blackmun announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 73–640. Dwight Geduldig, etc., appellant, v. Carolyn Aiello
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California. The stay heretofore granted by the Court on
October 15, 1973, is vacated. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Cali-

1

MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1974
642
fornia for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 73-781. Fritz Scherk, petitioner, v. Alberto-Culver Company.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with directions to remand to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall concur.
No. 73–804. George P. Baker et al., petitioners, v. Gold Seal
Liquors, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas announced
by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in
the result with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 19, 1974, at 10 o'clock.
☑



(Journal)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1974
643
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 73-206. Jacob J. Parker, Warden, et al., appellants, v. Howard
B. Levy. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Statement by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice
Brennan join. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 73-718. Bangor Punta Operations, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Bangor & Aroostook Railroad Company et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice
White join.
No. 73-593. Central Tablet Manufacturing Co., petitioner, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice
Powell join.
No. 73-831. Warden, Lewisburg Penitentiary, petitioner, v.
Benigno Marrero. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Douglas and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 72–6609. Eugenio and Alicia Jimenez, etc., appellants, v.
Caspar W. Weinberger. Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
540-278-74-119



WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1974
644
trict of Illinois. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
No. 73-5265. Henry A. Kokoszka, petitioner, v. Richard Belford,
Trustee, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, June 24, 1974, at 10 o'clock.



(Journal)
FRIDAY, JUNE 21, 1974
645
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1204. Rapides Police Jury et al, applicants, v. John Bradas
et al. The application for stay of the judgment of the United States
District Court for the Western District of Louisiana pending appeal
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, presented
to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr.
Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

(Journal)
MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1974
646
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73-499. Byrle L. Dillenburg, appellant, v. A. Ludlow Kramer,
Secretary of State of Washington, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Washington. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Douglas would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 73-521. Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, appellant, v. Annie J. Beaty. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of
appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 73–5598. Gregory Norton, Jr., a minor, etc., appellant, v.
Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States.
District Court for the District of Maryland for further consideration
in light of Jimenez v. Weinberger, 417 U.S. (1974).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 73–289. Carlyle Michelman, Trustee, etc., petitioner, v. George
Walter Kingswood and Gerd Kingswood. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Kokoszka v. Belford, 417 U.S.- (1974).
No. 73-877. Local 2150, International Brotherhood of Electrical
Workers, AFL-CIO, petitioner, v. National Labor Relations Board
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
540-278-74- -121

1
k

MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1974
647
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Florida Power and Light Co. v.
International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 641, et al.,
U.S.
(1974).
No. 73-1209. United States Board of Parole, petitioner, v. Hector
S. Amaya. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Warden v. Marrero, 417 U.S.
-(1974). Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant certiorari, and affirm judgment for the reasons stated in Mr.
Justice Blackmun's dissenting opinion in Warden v. Marrero, 417
U.S.
(1974).
-
No. 73-1404. Virginia McLaughlin, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Ana Soria Prieto and Eleanor Virellas. On petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Motion of respondent Prieto for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration
in light of Warden v. Marrero, 417 U.S. (1974). Mr. Justice
Douglas and Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari and affirm
judgment for the reasons stated in Mr. Justice Blackmun's dissenting
opinion in Warden v. Marrero, 417 U.S.
(1974).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1190. Joseph G. Scata, applicant, v. United States. The
application for stay of the mandate of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Mr. Justice Douglas, and
by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 48, Original. State of Mississippi, plaintiff, v. State of
Arkansas. It is ordered that the State of Arkansas file a response to the
request of the State of Mississippi for more specific boundary line
descriptions on or before July 24, 1974. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 73–235. Marco DeFunis et al., petitioners, v. Charles Ode-
gaard, President of the University of Washington, et al. The motion of
the respondents to retax costs is granted. Mr. Justice Douglas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 73-822. Ernest Fry and Thelma Boehm, petitioners, v. United
States. Consideration of the motion to dismiss the writ of certiorari
is deferred to the hearing of the case on the merits.



MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1974
648
No. 73-1210. Interstate Commerce Commission, appellant, v.
Oregon Pacific Industries, Inc., et al. The motion of Western Railroad.
Traffic Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, is granted..
No. 73–1766. United States, petitioner, v. Richard M. Nixon,
President of the United States, et al.; and
No. 73-1834. Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States,
petitioner, v. United States. Consideration of the motion of counsel
for the President for disclosure and transmittal of grand jury matters
is deferred to the hearing of the cases on the merits. Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
APPEAL JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 73-1346. John L. McLucas, Secretary of the Air Force, et al.,
appellants, v. Raymond G. DeChamplain. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia. In this case further
consideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hear-
ing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 73-324. Class of County Clerks and Registrars of Voters of
California, petitioners, v. Abran Ramirez et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California denied.
No. 73-549. Bell Supervisors Protective Association, petitioner,
v. National Labor Relations Board et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit denied.
No. 73-1024. California Newspapers. Inc., dba San Rafael Inde-
pendent Journal, petitioner, v. San Francisco Typographical Union
No. 21, International Typographical Union, AFL-CIO; and
No. 73-1199. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. San
Francisco Typographical Union No. 21, International Typographical
Union, AFL-CIO, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 73-1397. California, petitioner, v. Vivienne Ella Welton.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the
Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles, denied.
No. 73-5860. Eulogio Arias, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 73-6179. James Woodrow Cameron, Jr., petitioner, v. North
Carolina. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
North Carolina denied.



MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1974
649
No. 73–6617. Paul Toporoff, petitioner, v. Justices of the Supreme
Court of New York, First Judicial District et al. Petition for writ of

No. 73-5547. Oscar John Huguez, petitioner, v. California. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Black-
mun would grant certiorari.
No. 73-6319. Phillip Meeks, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appelate Court of Illinois, First District,
denied. Mr. Justice Douglas would grant certiorari.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Wednesday, June 26, 1974, until
Monday, July 8, 1974.

No. 72-1589. Viola N. Richardson, as County Clerk, etc., peti-
tioner, v. Abran Ramirez et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of California. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of California for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins and with whom Mr. Justice Douglas joins in Part I-A.
No. 73-507. William L. Hamling et al., petitioners, v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 73-557. Billy Jenkins, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Georgia for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Statement by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the result. Statement
by Justice Brennan concurring in the result with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.



MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1974
654
No. 73–263. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v.
Idaho Power Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.
No. 73-556. Florida Power & Light Co., petitioner, v. Interna-
tional Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 641, 622, 759, 820
and 1263, et al.; and
No. 73–795. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Inter-
national Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL-CIO, et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 73-918. Eve Pell, Betty Segal and Paul Jacobs, appellants,
v. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California Department of Cor-
rections, et al.: and
No. 73-754. Raymond K. Procunier, Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., appellants, v. Booker T. Hillery, Jr., et al.
Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern Dis-
trict of California. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of California.
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell con-
curring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall join in these cases and in No. 73–1265, post.
No. 73-1265. William B. Saxbe, Attorney General of the United
States, et al., petitioners, v. The Washington Post Co. et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join in this case
and in Nos. 73-918 and 73–754, ante. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.

No. 72-617. Elmer Gertz, petitioner, v. Robert Welch, Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 73-328. Harry J. Lehman, petitioner, v. City of Shaker
Heights et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun announced the judgment
of this Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
Marshall, and Mr. Justice Powell join.

of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO, et al., appellants, v. Henry M. Austin
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgments reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas concurring in
the result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.

No. 72-1690. Harold Omand Spence, appellant, v. Washington.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Washington for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Rehnquist with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice White join.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1220. William L. Calley, Jr., applicant, v. Howard H.
Callaway et al. The application to recall and stay the mandate of the
United States Court of Apppeals for the Fifth Circuit pending
applicant's peitition for rehearing en banc in that Court, presented to
Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, is denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINIONS
No. 73-38. United States, appellant, v. Marine Bancorporation,
Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Western District of Washington. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice
Douglas took no part in the decision of this case.
No. 73-767. United States, appellant, v. The Connecticut National
Bank et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Connecticut. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the District of Connecticut for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice White con-
curring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Douglas,
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 73–473. Daniel T. Taylor, III, petitioner, v. John P. Hayes,
Judge, Jefferson Circuit Court, Criminal Branch, Second Division.
On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky
for further proceeding not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice Douglas joins Parts II
and III of this opinion. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall dissenting
in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins as to Part II in this case and in
No. 73-5615, post.
No. 73-5615. Dominick Codispoti and Herbert Langnes, peti-
tioners, v. Pennsylvania. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Western District. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District,
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins as to Part II in this case and
in No. 73-473, ante.

No. 73-679. Charles Wolff, Jr., etc., et al., petitioners, . Robert

of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, re-

with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion

Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart join.

(Journal)
MONDAY, JULY 8, 1974
659
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 70-102. William Cahn, District Attorney, Nassau County,
et al., appellants, v. Long Island Vietnam Moratorium Committee et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment in Long Island Vietnam Moratorium Committee v.
Cahn, 437 F. 2d 344 (1970), affirmed. Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist dissent and would reverse judgment for the reasons
stated in Mr. Justice Rehnquist's dissenting opinion in Spence v.
Washington, 418 U.S.
(1974). Judgment in Gwathmey v.
Town of East Hampton, 437 F. 2d 351 (1970), vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971), and Samuels v. Mackell, 401
U.S. 66 (1971). Mr. Justice Douglas would affirm judgment for the
reasons stated in his dissenting opinion in Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S.
37, 58 (1971).
No. 72-1439. Glen Van Slyke, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 73-380. Linda Marie Sutherland et al., appellants, v. Illinois.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois,
Third District, for further consideration in light of Spence v. Wash-
ington, 418 U.S. — (1974) and Smith v. Goguen, 415 U.S.
(1974). The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun,
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent and without further briefing and
oral argument would affirm judgment.
-
580-278-74-125



MONDAY, JULY 8, 1974
660
No. 73–574. Patricia M. Farrell, appellant, v. Iowa. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Iowa. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Iowa for further consideration in light of
Spence v. Washington, 418 U.S. (1974). The Chief Justice, Mr.
Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dis-
sent and without further briefing and oral argument would affirm
judgment.
No. 73-1222. Tidewater Oil Company, appellant, v. United States
et al.; and
No. 73–1224. Phillips Petroleum Company, appellant, v. United
States et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Central District of California. Judgment affirmed.
No. 73–1366. Joseph H. Weston, appellant, v. Arkansas. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Douglas would reverse on the basis
of his dissenting opinion in Gertz v. Robert Welch, Inc., 418 U.S.
(1974).
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 72-1359. Richard P. Heffernan, Prosecuting Attorney of the
Sixteenth Circuit Court of the State of Connecticut, petitioner, v.
William P. Thoms, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Spence v. Washing-
ton, 418 U.S.
(1974) and Steffel v. Thompson, 415 U.S.
(1974). Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent and with-
out further briefing and oral argument would reverse judgment for
the reasons stated in Part I of Mr. Justice White's dissenting opinion
in Smith v. Goguen, 415 U.S.
(1974) and in Mr. Justice
Rehnquist's dissenting opinion in Spence v. Washington, 418 U.S.
"
(1974).
No. 72-1509. Gregory L. Porter, petitioner, v. Guam Publications,
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Gertz v. Robert Welch, Inc., 418
U.S. (1974). Mr. Justice White would affirm judgment on the
grounds that the publication was privileged under the laws of Guam.
No. 73-787. Aubrey Grossman, petitioner, v. Donald Striepeke,
Sheriff of County of Sonoma, California. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

OPINION
No. 72-1713. Secretary of the Navy, appellant, v. Mark Avrech.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the result. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

William C. Gribble, Jr., et al. The motion of Sonoma County Water
Agency et al. to vacate stay heretofore granted by Mr. Justice Douglas
on June 17, 1974, is denied.
,

etc. The motion of Wilson et al. to vacate stay heretofore granted by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist on June 20, 1974, is denied.

pany et al. The application to vacate the stay order of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, presented to Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Mr. Justice
Douglas would grant the application.

States, et al., appellants, v. American Civil Liberties Union, Inc., et al.

case, presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court,
is granted.
540-278-74-127



(Journal)
WEDNESDAY, JULY 24, 1974
669
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, and Mr. Justice Powell.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before we proceed today with the regular business of the Court,
it is my sad duty to take note for the Record and the Journal of this
Court of the death of our beloved colleague and friend Chief Justice
Warren, who served as Chief Justice of the United States from 1953
to 1969.
"His retirement on June 23, 1969, completed a career of public
service of more than a half-century, a career that has few parallels in
modern time.
"I speak for all the present and former members of the Court today
in expressing our deep sorrow at his death, and our profound sym-
pathy for Mrs. Warren and her family.
"On an appropriate occasion after the opening of the next Term
of the Court, a memorial service will be conducted for Chief Justice
Warren in this Chamber."
OPINION
No. 73-1766. United States, petitioner, v. Richard M. Nixon,
President of the United States, et al.; and
No. 73-1834. Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States,
petitioner, v. United States. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia
in No. 73-1766 affirmed. Writ of certiorari in No. 73-1834 dismissed
as improvidently granted. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision
of these cases.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
