(Journal)
THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
670
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
OPINION
No. 73-434. William G. Milliken, Governor of Michigan, et al.,
petitioners, v. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother
and next friend, Verda Bradley, et al.;
No. 73-435. Allen Park Public Schools et al., petitioners, v. Ronald
Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next friend, Verda
Bradley, et al.; and
No. 73-436. The Grosse Pointe Public School System, petitioner,
2. Ronald Bradley and Richard Bradley, by their mother and next
friend, Verda Bradley, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice White join.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 73–1280. Louis Watkins, appellant, v. South Carolina. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The appeal is dismissed.
for want of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas being of the view that any state
should be afforded a new trial under local community ban on obscenity
is prohibited by the First Amendment, made applicable to the States
by the Fourteenth (see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49,
70–73 (1973) (Douglas, J., dissenting)), would note jurisdiction and
reverse the judgment of conviction.
540-278-74- -129



THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
671
No. 73-1508. Marvin Miller, appellant, v. California. Appeal from
the Appellate Department of the Superior Court of California, County
of Orange. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas,
being of the view that any state ban on obscenity is prohibited by the
First Amendment, made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth
(see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would note jurisdiction and reverse the
judgment of conviction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
_
U.S.
No. 73–844. James M. Trinkler, petitioner, v. Alabama. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Ala-
bama. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for fur-
ther consideration in light of Hamling v. United States - U.S.
(1974), and Jenkins v. Georgia,
(1974). Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being
of the view that any state ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First
Amendment, made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth (see
Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973) (Douglas,
J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment
of conviction.
No. 73-1430. Board of Education of Jefferson County, Kentucky,
et al., petitioners, v. Newburg Area Council, Inc., et al.;
No. 73-1431. Board of Education of Louisville, Kentucky, et al.,
petitioners, v. John E. Haycraft et al.; and
No. 73-1445. Board of Education of Anchorage, Kentucky, et al.,
petitioners, v. John E. Haycraft et al. On petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Petitions for writs of certiorari granted. Judgments vacated and cases
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Milliken v. Bradley, U.S. (1974). Mr. Justice Douglas
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant certiorari and without further briefing or oral argument
affirm the judgments.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 73-1162. United States, petitioner, v. Thomas Joseph Wilson
and Bobby Antonio Bryan. It is ordered that John S. Martin, Jr.,
of New York, New York, a member of the Bar of this Court, be, and



THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
672
he is hereby, appointed to serve as counsel for respondent Bryan in
this case.
No. 73–2014. Missouri Portland Cement Company, petitioner, v.
Cargill, Incorporated. The motion of respondent to vacate the stay
heretofore entered by Mr. Justice Douglas on July 12, 1974, is granted.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 73-528. Gary Gilbert Carlson and Thomas Norris Truax,
petitioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of
the view that any federal ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First
Amendment (see United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S.
123, 130–138 (1973) (Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari
and reverse the judgment of conviction.
No. 73-584. Alan David Sians, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join
Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any federal ban on ob-
scenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see United States v.
12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973) (Douglas, J.,
dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment of con-
viction.
No. 73-788. Robert Brown, aka Bob Brown, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any federal
ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see United
States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgment of conviction.
No. 73-908. Robert E. Cote, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any
federal ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see
United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 US. 123, 130–138 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgment of conviction.



THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
673
No. 73-937. J-R Distributors. Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Washing-
ton. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington denied. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any state
ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment, made appli-
cable to the States by the Fourteenth (see Paris Adult Theatre I v.
Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973) (Douglas, J., dissenting)), would
grant certiorari and reverse the judgment of conviction.
No. 73–1060. Village Books, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Arthur
Marshall, Jr., State's Attorney for Prince George's County, Maryland.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland
denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas,
being of the view that any state ban on obscenity is prohibited by the
First Amendment, made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth
(see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton. 413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgment below.
No. 73-1075. Michael G. Thevis, petitioner, v. United States: and
No. 73-1091. Peachtree News Company, Inc., petitioner, v. United
States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any federal
ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see United
States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film. 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgments of conviction.
No. 73-1076. Frank Cangiano and Cosmo Cangiano, petitioners,
v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any federal
ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see United
States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413, U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgment of conviction.
No. 73–1136. Werner Ernest Enskat, petitioner, v. California.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
Second Appellate District, denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any state ban on
obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment, made applicable to



THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
674
the States by the Fourteenth (see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton,
413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973) (Douglas, J., dissenting)), would grant
certiorari and reverse the judgment of conviction.
No. 73-1161. Paris Adult Theatre I et al., petitioners, v. Lewis R.
Slaton, as District Attorney, Atlanta Judicial Circuit, et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of
the view that any state ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First
Amendment, made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth (see
Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70–73 (1973) (Douglas,
J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment
below.
No. 73-1241. Adult Film Association of America et al.. petitioners,
v. Malcolm M. Lucas, District Judge of United States District Court
for the Central District of California (William B. Saxbe, Attorney
General of United States, et al., real parties in interest). Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any
federal ban on obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see
United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film. 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973)
(Douglas, J., dissenting)) would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgment below.
No. 73–1260. James Jay Kaplan, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Jus-
tice Douglas, being of the view that any federal ban on obscenity is
prohibited by the First Amendment (see United States v. 12 200-ft.
Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973) (Douglas J., dissenting)),
would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment of conviction.
No. 73-1339. Robert Boyd, petitioner, v. Ohio. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Allen County, denied.
Mr. Justice Douglas. being of the view that any state ban on ob-
scenity is prohibited by the First Amendment, made applicable to
the States by the Fourteenth (see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton. 413
U.S. 49, 70–73 (1973) (Douglas J., dissenting)). would grant cer-
tiorari and reverse the judgment of conviction.
No. 73-1605. Jim Buckley and Al Goldstein, petitioners, v. New
York. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New
York denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Doug-
las, being of the view that any state ban on obscenity is prohibited
540-278-74--130



THURSDAY, JULY 25, 1974
675
by the First Amendment, made applicable to the States by the Four-
teenth (see Paris Adult Theatre I v. Slaton, 413 U.S. 49, 70-73 (1973)
(Douglas J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the
judgments of conviction.
No. 73-2001. John N. Mitchell and Kenneth Wells Parkinson,
petitioners, v. John J. Sirica, Judge, United States District Court.
Motion to expedite granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit denied. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 73-5927. Thomas Justin Millican, etc., petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
join. Mr. Justice Douglas, being of the view that any federal ban on
obscenity is prohibited by the First Amendment (see United States
v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123, 130–138 (1973) (Douglas,
J., dissenting)), would grant certiorari and reverse the judgment of
conviction;
REHEARING DENIED
No. 73-1650. Otto Kerner, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Motion
to expedite granted. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and
petition.
ASSIGNMENT ORDERS
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit during the period beginning
November 25, 1974, and ending November 29, 1974, and for such addi-
tional time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pur-
suant to 28 U.S.C. § 294 (a), is ordered entered on the minutes of
this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Mr. Jus-
tice Clark (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York during the
period beginning December 2, 1974, and ending December 24, 1974,
and for such additional time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

683
The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
"It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
